Tomaselli G.F. Goldschmidt-Clermont P.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 1510-1514Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar). The extracts were normalized, then ultracentrifuged at 100,000 × g (Beckman TL100) in polycarbonate tubes at 4° C. The pellets were carefully rinsed (but not disrupted) with lysis buffer. Then, 200 μl of methanol was added to each pellet to resolubilize the rhodamine phalloidin. The samples were vortexed for 30 s and incubated overnight prior to being transferred to individual wells of a 96-well Costar plate for quantitation of rhodamine fluorescence in a CytoFluor 2300 (Millipore). Standard curves providing rhodamine phalloidin fluorescence as a function of actin concentration were also obtained to validate the assay. Serial dilution of rabbit muscle actin were polymerized by addition of 2 mM MgCl2. After 60 min, samples were diluted (1 to 10) in lysis buffer supplemented with rhodamine phalloidin (0.6 μM), ultracentrifuged, and processed for rhodamine measurements as described for the cell extracts. Blanks corresponded to duplicate samples, but lysed in the presence of excess unlabeled phalloidin (100 μM, Sigma) and provided an estimate of the background fluorescence that was subtracted from actual data. The fluorometer settings were excitation at 530 and emission at 590 nm. A replication incompetent adenovirus (ad-SOD) carrying the cDNA for human CuZn-SOD was constructed as reported to overexpress superoxide dismutase in endothelial cells (22McGrory W.J. Bautista D.S. Graham F.L. Virology. 1988; 163: 614-617Crossref PubMed Scopus (550) Google Scholar). Another virus, dl312 (a generous gift from T. Shenk) (23Jonos N. Shenk T. Cell. 1979; 17: 683-689Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (476) Google Scholar), carrying a similar genomic backbone (Ad.5 serotype, E1-deleted) but without the SOD-cDNA was used as a control. AEC were grown to confluence in Corning 96-well plates (0.5 × 105 cells/well) in complete medium. Serial dilution of ad-SOD were added in triplicate to 24 of the 96 wells, with multiplicity of infection (m.o.i.) ranging from 80 to 1. The same serial dilution (m.o.i.) of the dl312 virus were tested in another 24 wells. After 4 days of infection, the wells were washed once in PBS and then fixed in 3.7% formaldehyde in PBS. The cells were permeabilized in 0.2% Triton X-100 in PBS for 15 min, and fluorescently labeled with an anti-SOD monoclonal antibody (1:500 dilution) and fluorescein isothiocyanate-labeled goat anti-mouse antibody (1:50). Fluorescein isothiocyanate fluorescence was measured in CytoFluor 2300 with an excitation of 485 nm and an emission of 530. SOD activity in cellular extracts was measured by the inhibition of reduction of cytochrome c (24McCord J.M. Fridovich I. J. Biol. Chem. 1969; 244: 6049-6055Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). After 4 h of hypoxia, resulting in a progressive reduction of pO2 to 10 ± 5 torr, AEC displayed an actin superstructure that was essentially similar to that of control, non-hypoxic cells (Fig. 1). However, after 5 min of re-exposure to normoxic conditions, rapid assembly of actin filaments was observed in previously hypoxic AEC (Fig. 2). Filamentous actin content increased by an average of 41% (±12.2%, S.E., p = 0.036) over base-line level (Fig. 2). Concurrently with the polymerization reaction, redistribution of actin filaments took place, with disappearance of cell spanning actin stress fibers, thickening of the cortical actin network and extension of membrane ruffles (Fig. 1). As we have shown that reoxygenated AEC produce ROS and in particular superoxide (18Zweier J.L. Broderick R. Kuppusamy P. Thompson-Gorman S. Lutty G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 24156-24162Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), we next studied the role of superoxide in the actin response of post-hypoxic AEC.Fig. 2Actin polymerization in reoxygenated AEC. a, filamentous actin was measured in extracts from control, hypoxic (240 min, ∼10 torr), and reoxygenated cells (5 and 45 min) (solid circles). While the concentration of filamentous actin was not affected by 240 min of hypoxia, reoxygenation resulted in rapid (5 min) polymerization of actin filaments. After 45 min in normoxic conditions, the concentration of filamentous actin was no longer significantly different from base-line levels. The data were normalized to the filamentous actin content of the cells at base-line level (100%). Each data point corresponds to the mean of six experiments (± S.E.). The actin filament content was significantly increased at 5 min of reoxygenation (* indicates p = 0.036). Exposure of the cells to the tyrosine kinase inhibitor, genistein (200 μM), led to complete suppression of the polymerization response (open circles). b, standard curve for filamentous actin. Rabbit muscle actin was polymerized, labeled with rhodamine phalloidin and processed as for the cellular extracts. On this representative data set, the relationship between F-actin and rhodamine fluorescence is linear. The x axis corresponds to actin concentration prior to dilution in lysis buffer.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) Confluent plates of AEC were infected for 24 h either with ad-SOD dismutase at an m.o.i. of 40, or with the control dl312 at the same m.o.i. Three days after infection, overexpression of CuZn-SOD was confirmed by detecting the protein in permeabilized infected AEC, using a immunofluorescence assay and by measuring enzymatic activity (Fig. 3). While in control cells infected with dl312 we detected background level of CuZn-SOD, the concentration of enzyme in AEC infected with the ad-SOD increased as a function of the m.o.i. (Fig. 3, a and b). Dismutase activity was low in control cells (dl312), but was markedly increased in extracts of ad-SOD-infected cells (4.5-fold at m.o.i. 80), proportionally to the virus over cell ratio and the SOD concentration (Fig. 3). Next, 3 days after infection of AEC with ad-SOD or dl312 (m.o.i. of 40), cells were exposed to hypoxia (240 min) and 5 min of reoxygenation, lysed, and F-actin in the extract was measured using the rhodamine phalloidin assay. While in cells infected with dl312, there was a significant increase in F-actin (25 ± 7.2%, mean ± S.E.) over base-line level, in AEC overexpressing superoxide dismutase there was no increase in F-actin content, and even a small drop in F-actin was detected (Fig. 3c). Qualitative analysis by fluorescence microscopy of reoxygenated AEC overexpressing SOD fixed at 5 min demonstrated the absence of actin filament redistribution in these cells (Fig. 4).Fig. 4Inhibition of actin response to reoxygenation in AEC treated with genistein or SOD. AEC were exposed to hypoxia (240 min, ∼10 torr), then to normoxic conditions for (a) 45 min for cells pretreated for 1 h with genistein (200 μM); or (b) 5 min for cells infected with the ad-SOD at an m.o.i. of 40. Note that in contrast with what was observed in control AEC (Fig. 1), reoxygenation of endothelial cells pretreated with genistein led to progressive collapse of the actin cytoskeleton, with absence of stress fibers and clustering of filaments into small patches. In AEC overexpressing SOD, there was no redistribution of actin filaments to the periphery associated with reoxygenation, and the actin stress fibers were present throughout hypoxia and reoxygenation. The micrographs are representative of ≥100 cells per condition. The bar is 12 μm.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) Because of the known coupling between ROS production and tyrosine kinase pathways, we studied tyrosine phosphorylation in reoxygenated AEC by Western blot analysis and densitometry, and observed that there was a small but significant (p = 0.035) increase in tyrosine-phosphorylated substrates in reoxygenated AEC compared to base-line, normoxic cells (Fig. 5). Particularly, extracts corresponding to the first few seconds of reoxygenation contained more tyrosine-phosphorylated substrates than base-line samples (2.28-fold increase). The tyrosine phosphorylation increase required superoxide production in the reoxygenated AEC. Overexpression of SOD using ad-SOD infection resulted in the inhibition of both base-line and hypoxia/reoxygenation-induced tyrosine phosphorylation (Fig. 5). Suppression of tyrosine phosphorylation in AEC could be also obtained with genistein (data not shown), an isoflavone compound which has a well established inhibitory effect on tyrosine kinases (21Furman M.I. Grigoryev D. Bray P.F. Dise K.R. Goldschmidt-Clermont P.J. Circ. Res. 1994; 75: 172-180Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar, 25Akiyama T. Ishida J. Nakagawa S. Ogawara H. Watanabe S. Itoh N. Shibuya M. Fukami Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 5592-5595Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We assessed the ability of genistein to suppress the actin response to the respiratory burst. The presence of genistein led to complete inhibition of the actin polymerization response to reoxygenation in endothelial cells (Fig. 2). However, in contrast with SOD overexpression which also suppressed the actin polymerization but had no significant effect on the organization of the actin cytoskeleton 45 min after reoxygenation (data not shown), marked alteration of the actin cytoskeleton was seen with genistein following reoxygenation (Fig. 4). We observed formation of patches of actin filaments and inhibition of ruffle formation. Upon analyzing the response of genistein-treated AEC to reoxygenation by video microscopy, we observed the collapse of the endothelial cell superstructure (data not shown), instead of the rapid recovery of a normal structure in the absence of genistein (Fig. 1). Our data support the hypothesis that following a period of hypoxia, AEC re-exposed to oxygen undergo structural changes which, perhaps, play an important role in priming endothelial cells for angiogenesis. We have shown that superoxide generation is a prerequisite for actin polymerization in hypoxic and reoxygenated AEC. At least two mechanisms could be responsible for the actin response to superoxide production. (i) Superoxide could affect endothelial cell signaling pathways (Fig. 5) which subsequently may regulate the actin cytoskeleton (11Sundaresan M. Yu Z.-X. Ferrans V.J. Irani K. Finkel T. Science. 1995; 270: 296-299Crossref PubMed Scopus (2322) Google Scholar). (ii) Superoxide (or derived ROS) may directly affect the actin cytoskeleton (26Chai Y.C. Ashraf S.S. Rokutan K. Johnston Jr., R.B. Thomas J.A. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1994; 310: 273-281Crossref PubMed Scopus (198) Google Scholar), by changing the redox state of actin regulatory proteins (sequestering or capping proteins) or of actin itself, thereby inducing actin polymer formation. Consistent with the latter hypothesis, S-thiolation of actin has been shown in association with respiratory bursts (27Omann G.M. Harter J.M. Burger J.M. Hinshaw D.B. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1994; 308: 407-412Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar), and the sulfoxide isoform of the most abundant actin sequestering protein in mammalian cells, thymosin-β4, is unable to sequester actin monomers (28Heintz D. Reichert A. Mihelic-Rapp M. Stoeva S. Voelter W. Faulstich H. Eur. J. Biochem. 1994; 223: 345-350Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). Considering the rather limited extent of the tyrosine kinase response to reoxygenation (Fig. 5), it is likely that a combination of the two mechanisms (i and ii) mediates the actin changes observed with reoxygenation. Interestingly, genistein inhibition of tyrosine phosphorylation in reoxygenated cells induced the collapse of the actin superstructure, a change that goes far beyond the simple reversal of the remodeling of the cytoskeleton observed with reoxygenation (Fig. 4). No such collapse was observed upon inhibition of the tyrosine kinase response to reoxygenation in cells by overexpressing SOD. Hence, the cross-interaction between the oxidases producing superoxide and tyrosine kinases/phosphatases seems to be tightly regulated to lead to the reorganization of the actin cytoskeleton but preserves the integrity of the actin superstructure of endothelial cells. It is possible that the transient changes in the organization of the actin cytoskeleton mediated by oxidases contribute not only to the increased permeability of reoxygenated endothelial cells (29Lum H. Barr D.A. Shaffer J.R. Gordon R.J. Ezrin A.M. Malik A.B. Circ. Res. 1992; 70: 991-998Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar), but also, in concert with growth factors and their receptors, to the development of an angiogenic response. Activation of most of the small GTP binding proteins of the p21ras family, including Rac1, has been shown by us and others to generate ROS (13Sulciner D.J. Irani K. Yu Z.-X. Ferrans V.J. Goldschmidt-Clermont P.-J. Finkel T. Biochem. J. 1996; 318: 379-382Crossref PubMed Scopus (441) Google Scholar) and to induce specific changes in the organization of the actin cytoskeleton (14Ridley A.J. Paterson H.F. Johnston C.L. Diekmann D. Hall A. Cell. 1992; 70: 401-410Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3084) Google Scholar, 15Ridley A.J. Hall A. Cell. 1992; 70: 389-399Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3843) Google Scholar, 16Nobes C.D. Hall A. Cell. 1995; 81: 53-62Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3747) Google Scholar, 17Heldman A.W. Tucker R.W. Crawford L.E. Kandzari D.E. Fearon E.R. Koblan K.S. Goldschmidt-Clermont P.J. Circ. Res. 1996; 78 (in press)Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). It is tempting to speculate at this point that ROS play a pivotal role in mediating the actin remodeling observed in cells activated by growth factor receptors, or by reoxygenation of previously hypoxic cells. We are in the process of testing this hypothesis using adenovirus constructs carrying either the cDNA for a dominant positive isoform (constitutively bound to GTP) or for a dominant negative isoform (constitutively bound to GDP) of Rac1 and overexpression of these isoforms in AEC.

Expression of α-amylase genes in cultured rice suspension cells is induced by sucrose starvation. To study the mechanism of sugar metabolite regulation on the expression of individual α-amylase genes, DNA fragments specific to each of eight rice α-amylase genes were synthesized and used as gene-specific probes. Comparison of the relative abundance of mRNA revealed that expression of the eight α-amylase genes in rice cells was differentially regulated by sucrose starvation. Accumulation of all the α-amylase mRNAs increased in response to sucrose starvation; however, levels of the αAmy3 and αAmy8 mRNAs were distinctly higher and constituted 90% of total α-amylase mRNAs. RNA gel blot and nuclear run-on transcription analyses demonstrated a positive correlation between the increased transcription rates and the elevated steady-state levels of α-amylase mRNAs induced by sucrose starvation. The half-lives of αAmy3, αAmy7, and αAmy8 were prolonged by sucrose-starvation; however, the stability of the three mRNAs seems controlled by different mechanisms. The translation inhibitors cycloheximide and anisomycin preferentially blocked the sucrose-suppressed expression of αAmy3 but not that of αAmy7 and αAmy8. These inhibitors also enhanced the sucrose starvation-induced accumulation of αAmy3 mRNA but not that of αAmy7 or αAmy8 mRNAs. Cycloheximide did not significantly alter the transcription rates of α-amylase genes, suggesting that labile proteins may selectively stabilize the αAmy7 and αAmy8 mRNAs but destabilize the αAmy3 mRNA. Expression of α-amylase genes in cultured rice suspension cells is induced by sucrose starvation. To study the mechanism of sugar metabolite regulation on the expression of individual α-amylase genes, DNA fragments specific to each of eight rice α-amylase genes were synthesized and used as gene-specific probes. Comparison of the relative abundance of mRNA revealed that expression of the eight α-amylase genes in rice cells was differentially regulated by sucrose starvation. Accumulation of all the α-amylase mRNAs increased in response to sucrose starvation; however, levels of the αAmy3 and αAmy8 mRNAs were distinctly higher and constituted 90% of total α-amylase mRNAs. RNA gel blot and nuclear run-on transcription analyses demonstrated a positive correlation between the increased transcription rates and the elevated steady-state levels of α-amylase mRNAs induced by sucrose starvation. The half-lives of αAmy3, αAmy7, and αAmy8 were prolonged by sucrose-starvation; however, the stability of the three mRNAs seems controlled by different mechanisms. The translation inhibitors cycloheximide and anisomycin preferentially blocked the sucrose-suppressed expression of αAmy3 but not that of αAmy7 and αAmy8. These inhibitors also enhanced the sucrose starvation-induced accumulation of αAmy3 mRNA but not that of αAmy7 or αAmy8 mRNAs. Cycloheximide did not significantly alter the transcription rates of α-amylase genes, suggesting that labile proteins may selectively stabilize the αAmy7 and αAmy8 mRNAs but destabilize the αAmy3 mRNA. Carbon catabolite repression is a fundamental and ubiquitous regulatory system in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells (1Entian K.-D. Barnett J.A. Trends Biol. Sci. 1992; 17: 506-510Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar, 2Gancedo J.M. Eur. J. Biochem. 1992; 206: 297-313Crossref PubMed Scopus (297) Google Scholar, 3McGrane M.M. Yun J.S. Patel Y.M. Hanson R.W. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1992; 17: 40-44Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar, 4Saier Jr., M.H. New Biol. 1991; 3: 1137-1147PubMed Google Scholar). In bacteria and yeast, catabolite-regulated gene expression is an essential mechanism for adjusting to changes in nutrient availability (5Carlson M. J. Bacteriol. 1987; 169: 4873-4877Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 6Schuster J.R. Barr P.J. Brike A.J. Valenzuela P. Yeast Genetic Engineering. Butterworths, London1989: 83Google Scholar, 7Vyas N.K. Vyas M.N. Quiocho F.A. Science. 1988; 242: 1290-1295Crossref PubMed Scopus (332) Google Scholar). Studies using Saccharomyces cerevisiae mutants have revealed many of the components involved in the response to carbon catabolite repression, but it is still unclear how all of these components interact to regulate transcription (2Gancedo J.M. Eur. J. Biochem. 1992; 206: 297-313Crossref PubMed Scopus (297) Google Scholar, 8Trumbly R.J. Mol. Microbiol. 1992; 6: 15-21Crossref PubMed Scopus (269) Google Scholar). In higher plants, carbon metabolite regulation of gene expression provides a mechanism for maintaining an economical balance between supply (source) and demand (sink) for carbohydrate allocation and utilization within and among various organs and tissues (9Sheen J. Photosynth. Res. 1994; 39: 427-438Crossref PubMed Scopus (284) Google Scholar). Expression of enzymes involved in carbohydrate metabolism often is feedback-regulated by the sugar metabolites (9Sheen J. Photosynth. Res. 1994; 39: 427-438Crossref PubMed Scopus (284) Google Scholar). For example, expression of seven maize photosynthetic genes in mesophyll protoplasts is repressed by sucrose and the mechanism involves transcriptional control (10Sheen J. Plant Cell. 1990; 2: 1027-1038Crossref PubMed Scopus (565) Google Scholar). Phosphorylation of hexose sugars by hexokinase has been proposed to act as a key signal transmitter in initiating sugar repression responses of photosynthetic genes (11Jang J.-C. Sheen J. Plant Cell. 1994; 6: 1665-1679Crossref PubMed Scopus (566) Google Scholar), and of malate synthase and isocitrate lyase genes involved in the glyoxylate cycle (12Graham I.A. Denby K.J. Leaver C.J. Plant Cell. 1994; 6: 761-772Crossref PubMed Scopus (253) Google Scholar). α-Amylases are major amylolytic enzymes for hydrolysis of stored starch in the endosperm during germination of cereal grains. In germinating cereal grains, gibberellic acid stimulates and abscisic acid represses α-amylase gene expression (reviewed in 13Jacobsen J.V. Chandler P.M. Davies P.J. Plant Hormones and Their Role in Plant Growth and Development. Martinus Nijhoff, Dordrecht, The Netherlands1987: 164Crossref Google Scholar). We have previously reported that expression of α-amylase genes in rice is under two different modes of tissue-specific regulation; the genes are activated by hormones in the aleurone of germinating seed and suppressed by sugars in cultured suspension cells (14Yu S.-M. Kuo Y.-H. Sheu G. Sheu Y.-J. Liu L.-F. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 21131-21137Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 15Yu S.-M. Tzou W.-S. Lo W.-S. Kuo Y.-H. Lee H.-T. Wu R. Gene (Amst.). 1992; 122: 247-253Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). Later, expression of one α-amylase gene in the embryo of germinating rice seed was also reported to be suppressed by sugars (16Karrer E.E. Rodriguez R.L. Plant J. 1992; 2: 517-523PubMed Google Scholar). Recently, we observed that sugars that accumulate in the embryo and endosperm during germination act as signals and osmotica to regulate the expression of α-amylase genes and the metabolic activities in germinating rice seeds (17Yu S.-M. Lee Y.-C. Fang S.-C. Chan M.-T. Hwa S.-F. Liu L.-F. Plant Mol. Biol. 1996; 30: 1277-1289Crossref PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar). To study the mechanism of metabolite regulation of α-amylase gene expression in plants, we have used the cultured rice suspension cells as a model system. Previous work shows that, in cultured rice suspension cells, α-amylase expression, carbohydrate metabolism, and vacuolar autophagy are coordinately regulated by sucrose levels in the medium (18Chen M.-H. Liu L.-F. Chen Y.-R. Wu H.-K. Yu S.-M. Plant J. 1994; 6: 625-636Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar). Both the transcription rate and mRNA stability of α-amylase genes in cells increase in response to sucrose depletion in the culture medium (19Sheu J.-J Jan S.-P. Lee H.-T. Yu S.-M. Plant J. 1994; 5: 655-664Crossref Scopus (66) Google Scholar). Use of transgenic rice carrying an α-amylase gene promoter/β-glucuronidase gene proved that the regulation of α-amylase gene expression by sugars involves a transcriptional control mechanism (20Chan M.-T. Chang H.-H. Ho S.-L. Tong W.-F. Yu S.-M. Plant Mol. Biol. 1993; 22: 491-506Crossref PubMed Scopus (192) Google Scholar, 21Chan M.-T. Chao Y.-C. Yu S.-M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 17635-17641Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 22Huang N. Chandler J. Thomas B.R. Koizumi N. Rodriguez R.L. Plant Mol. Biol. 1993; 23: 737-747Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar). Our previous study on metabolite regulation involved measurement at the total α-amylase mRNA level rather than dealing with the individual mRNA encoding different α-amylase isozymes. To further study the mechanism(s) of metabolite regulation in detail, it is necessary to identify the individual α-amylase genes whose expression is regulated by sugars. This report demonstrates that the expression of various α-amylase genes in rice suspension cells is regulated in a coordinated way by sucrose present in the medium, but in a distinctly different manner according to the specific α-amylase genes. Both transcription rate and mRNA stability contribute to the regulation of the transcript level of the individual α-amylase gene. Suspension cell cultures of rice (Oryza sativa cv. Tainan 5) were propagated as described previously (14Yu S.-M. Kuo Y.-H. Sheu G. Sheu Y.-J. Liu L.-F. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 21131-21137Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Cells for purification of RNA were collected by filtration through a 400-mesh nylon sieve, blot-dried on paper towels, quick-frozen in liquid N2, and stored at −70°C until use. Plasmid pRY18 carries a 3.8-kb DNA fragment, which contains a rice genomic rDNA cluster, including the 3′ half portion of 17 S rRNA, the complete 5.8 S rRNA, and the 5′ half portion of 25 S rRNA genes in pUC13 (24Sano Y. The paired 5′ and 3′ gene-specific primers derived from the regions surrounding the stop codons and the 3′-untranslated regions of various α-amylase genes (Fig. 1) were used for PCR. PCR was carried out in a 50-μl solution containing 15 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 60 mM KCl, 2.75 mM MgCl2, 10% Me2SO, 0.4 mM of each deoxynucleoside triphosphate (dATP, dCTP, dGTP, dTTP), 150 pmol of each primer, 0.5 μg of rice genomic DNA, and 2.5 units of Taq DNA polymerase (Promega). Cycling was controlled by a programmable thermal cycler (MJ Research) programmed with conditions described by Sambrook et al. (25Sambrook J. Fritsch R.F. Maniatis T. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. 2nd Ed. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1989Google Scholar). The annealing temperatures were 40°C for RAmy3A, 42°C for αAmy3, αAmy6, αAmy7, αAmy8, and αAmy10, and 45°C for RAmy1B and RAmy2A. The amplified DNA fragments were 91 bp for αAmy10, 124 bp for RAmy2A, 132 bp for αAmy7, 184 bp for αAmy6, 220 bp for RAmy3B, 221 bp for RAmy3A, 264 bp for αAmy8, and 288 bp for αAmy3. These DNA fragments were subcloned into pBluescript and sequenced. One gram of rice suspension cells was ground in liquid N2 with a mortar and pestle and placed in a 2-ml Eppendorf tube. The ground tissue was suspended in 1 ml of urea extraction buffer (containing 7 M urea, 0.3 M NaCl, 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 20 mM EDTA, and 1% sarkosine) and extracted with 1 ml of phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) at room temperature for 15 min. The mixture was centrifuged at 8000 rpm and 4°C for 10 min. The aqueous phase was mixed with 200 μl of 3 M sodium acetate (pH 5.2) and 1 ml of isopropanol. DNA was spooled out, placed in 70% ethanol, and centrifuged at 8000 rpm for 10 s. The DNA pellet was washed with 70% and 100% ethanol and air-dried. The genomic DNA was resuspended in TE buffer and stored at 4°C. Ten micrograms of genomic DNA was digested with various restriction enzymes and fractionated on a 0.8% agarose gel. The DNA gel blot analysis was performed as described by Sambrook et al. (25Sambrook J. Fritsch R.F. Maniatis T. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. 2nd Ed. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1989Google Scholar) using the α-amylase gene-specific DNAs as probes. The α-amylase gene-specific DNA fragments used as probes were excised from the plasmid vectors by appropriate restriction enzymes and labeled with [α-32P]dATP using the random primer method (26Feinberg A.P. Vogelstein B. Anal. Biochem. 1983; 132: 6-13Crossref PubMed Scopus (16653) Google Scholar). The 32P-labeled single-stranded cDNA probe was prepared from total cellular RNA using an oligo(dT) primer and avian myeloblastosis virus reverse transcriptase (Promega) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Plasmid DNA was denatured with 0.4 N NaOH at room temperature for 30 min, and neutralized with a 9-fold volume of 6 × SSC (containing 0.1% DNA agarose gel loading dye). The denatured DNA was blotted onto the Magna nylon membrane (MSI) using a suction slot-blotter (Life Technologies, Inc.) and hybridized with the cDNA probe. Hybridization was performed as described for DNA gel blot analysis (25Sambrook J. Fritsch R.F. Maniatis T. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. 2nd Ed. Lee H.-T. J. Virol. 1992; 66: 1442-1448Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Vogelstein B. Anal. Biochem. 1983; 132: 6-13Crossref PubMed Scopus (16653) Google Scholar). Because the nucleotide sequence identity among the coding regions of rice α-amylase genes ranges between 75 and 95% 2J.-J. Sheu, T.-S. Yu, W.-F. Tong, and S.-M. Yu, unpublished data. and the coding regions of rice actin genes are highly conserved (23McElroy D. Rothenberg M. Wu R. Plant Mol. Biol. 1990; 14: 163-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar), the αAmy8-C and Act1 cDNA containing coding region probably hybridize to the mRNAs of all α-amylase and actin genes. The α-amylase gene-specific DNA probes were prepared by PCR and labeled with [α-32P]dCTP using the random primer method. In each experiment the hybridized α-amylase DNA probe on the Magna nylon membrane was stripped off by incubating twice (30 min each) in washing solution containing 0.1 × SSC and 0.1% SDS at 90°C. The same membrane was rehybridized with different α-amylase gene-specific DNA probes or the actin cDNA probe. Nuclei were isolated from rice suspension cells as described by Watson and Thompson (29Watson J.C. Thompson W.F. Methods Enzymol. 1986; 118: 57-75Crossref Scopus (121) Google Scholar). Nuclear run-on transcription analysis was performed as described previously (19Sheu J.-J Jan S.-P. Lee H.-T. Yu S.-M. Plant J. 1994; 5: 655-664Crossref Scopus (66) Google Scholar). The rice α-amylase isozymes are encoded by nine genes (30Thomas B.R. Rodriguez R.L. Plant Physiol. 1994; 106: 1235-1239Crossref PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar). Nomenclature and accession numbers of the rice α-amylase genes in GenBank™ are shown in Table I. Comparison of nucleotide sequences of the 3′-untranslated regions (3′-UTR) of α-amylase genes shows low identity except between RAmy3B and RAmy3C (Fig. 1). There is also some similarity between the 3′-UTRs of αAmy7(Ramy1A) and αAmy10(RAmy1C); however, several gaps are distributed between their homologous regions. Primers locating at the 5′ and 3′ regions in the 3′-UTR of each of the eight α-amylase genes were designed (Fig. 1) so that amplification of DNA fragments flanked by the paired primers would yield gene-specific DNA fragments. Replicated gel blots of genomic DNA digested with various restriction enzymes were hybridized with the 32P-labeled α-amylase gene-specific probes. Each probe hybridized specifically to the α-amylase gene from which it was derived (Fig. 2A), demonstrating that the eight gene-specific probes were able to detect the individual α-amylase genes. To demonstrate over what range these probes can discriminate the mRNA of one gene from another, eight pieces of parallel prepared membranes containing three dilution series of each gene-specific DNA were hybridized with the individual probes. The result shows that only RAmy1B and RAmy1C probes slightly cross-hybridized with some of the other α-amylase gene-specific DNAs (Fig. 2B). Open table in a new tab The steady-state levels of α-amylase mRNA in rice suspension cells before and after sucrose starvation were examined by RNA gel blot analysis. Amount of rRNA was used as RNA amount loading control in the RNA gel blot analysis, although previously we have shown that the total transcription rate in cells provided with sucrose was twice that in cells starved for sucrose (19Sheu J.-J Jan S.-P. Lee H.-T. Yu S.-M. Plant J. 1994; 5: 655-664Crossref Scopus (66) Google Scholar). Accumulation of α-amylase mRNAs was very low or undetectable in cells provided with sucrose (Fig. 3, lane 2). In contrast, in sucrose-starved cells, accumulation of the α-amylase mRNAs increased (Fig. 3, lane 1). The magnitude of increase in mRNA concentrations varied with α-amylase genes and was particularly dramatic for αAmy3 and αAmy8. To compare the relative abundance of mRNA of the eight α-amylase genes, an excess of rice rRNA gene, actin cDNA, and α-amylase gene-specific DNAs was spotted onto a membrane and hybridized with the 32P-labeled, single-stranded cDNA probe transcribed from the total mRNA of sucrose-starved cells. The relative mRNA levels, corresponding to different genes in a given population of RNA, were then compared. The cDNA of the rRNA was also synthesized, probably due to the presence of the repeated short stretch of the poly(A) sequence in the rRNA (31Takaiwa G. Oono K. Sugiura M. Nucleic Acids Res. 1984; 12: 5441-5448Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar, 32Takaiwa G. Oono K. Iida Y. Sugiura M. Gene (Amst.). 1985; 37: 255-259Crossref PubMed Scopus (97) Google Scholar). In sucrose-starved cells, the amounts of αAmy3 and αAmy8 mRNAs were distinctly higher than those of other α-amylase genes (Fig. 4). The αAmy3 mRNA was the most abundant (Fig. 4, slot 9), with αAmy8 mRNA the next most abundant (Fig. 4, slot 10). Together the results shown in Fig. 3, Fig. 4 suggest that the α-amylase genes are subject to differential metabolic regulation at the transcriptional and/or post-transcriptional level. To define the mechanism that differentially regulates the expression of α-amylase genes, we compared the transcription rates of individual α-amylase genes. The nuclear run-on transcription analyses were performed with nuclei isolated from cells grown in the absence or presence of sucrose. In cells provided with sucrose, the transcription rates of all the α-amylase genes were undetectable (Fig. 5, upper panel). In contrast, in cells starved for sucrose for 12 h, the transcription rates of all the α-amylase genes increased, with αAmy3 the highest (Fig. 5, upper panel, slot 7) and αAmy8 the next highest (Fig. 5, upper panel, slot 8). In cells starved for 24 h (Fig. 5, lower panel), the transcription rates of all the tested genes decreased significantly; however, the transcription rates of αAmy3 and αAmy8 were still distinctly higher than that of the other α-amylase genes. Comparison of Fig. 4, Fig. 5 reveals that there is a positive correlation between the transcription rates and the steady-state levels of α-amylase mRNAs in cells starved for sucrose. To examine the effect of sucrose starvation on the half-life of individual α-amylase mRNA, degradation of the αAmy3, αAmy7, and αAmy8 mRNAs in vivo was monitored by RNA gel blot analysis following the inhibition of transcription with actinomycin D. Addition of 10 μg ml−1 actinomycin D to the medium has been shown previously to inhibit total RNA transcription by more than 95% over a 12-h time course (19Sheu J.-J Jan S.-P. Lee H.-T. Yu S.-M. Plant J. 1994; 5: 655-664Crossref Scopus (66) Google Scholar). The levels of individual α-amylase mRNAs were low in cells grown in the sucrose-containing medium (Fig. 6A, lane 1) and increased significantly after cells had been shifted to sucrose-free medium for 24, 36, and 45 h (Fig. 6A, lanes 2-4). The levels of individual α-amylase mRNAs that accumulated after cells have been starved for 24 h and then pretreated with actinomycin D in the absence of sucrose for 12 h (Fig. 6A, lane 5 or lane 13) decreased slowly during the subsequent 9-h incubation in the medium still lacking sucrose but containing actinomycin D (Fig. 6A, lanes 14-19). In contrast, the levels of α-amylase mRNA decreased with time during the 9-h incubation in the medium containing both sucrose and actinomycin D (Fig. 6A, lanes 6-12). The level of actin mRNA was high in cells grown in the presence of sucrose (Fig. 6A, lane 1), but was low in the absence of sucrose (Fig. 6A, lanes 2-4). In the medium containing actinomycin D, the levels of actin mRNA remained low regardless of the presence (Fig. 6A, lanes 5-12) or absence (Fig. 6A, lanes 13-19) of sucrose. The result of actin gene expression suggests that transcription of total mRNA was almost completely inhibited by actinomycin D; otherwise, accumulation of actin mRNA would increase in medium containing both sucrose and actinomycin D. The amounts of mRNA shown in Fig. 6A were quantified, and Fig. 6B shows the log plots of the α-amylase mRNA levels as a function of time. The half-life of mRNA was calculated from the slope of the line in the log plot of the data. The relative half-lives of αAmy3 and αAmy8, which were 82 and 98 min, respectively, in cells provided with sucrose, increased to 6 h in cells starved for sucrose (Fig. 6B). Both the half-lives of αAmy3 and αAmy8 mRNAs were substantially shorter than that of αAmy7 mRNA, regardless of the presence or absence of sucrose in the medium. The relative half-life of αAmy7 was almost 5 h in cells provided with sucrose and increased to 23 h in cells starved for sucrose. These results suggest that the α-amylase mRNAs are more stable in cells starved for sucrose. To examine whether the increase in mRNA levels of various α-amylase genes requires a prior synthesis of other gene products, cells were treated with translation inhibitors and accumulation of mRNA was monitored with RNA gel blot analysis. Levels of α-amylase mRNAs were very low or almost undetectable in cells provided with sucrose (Fig. 7A, lanes 1 and 2), but increased greatly in cells starved for sucrose for 2 days (Fig. 7A, lanes 8 and 9). Cycloheximide, an inhibitor of translocase (33Galling G. Encycl. Plant Physiol. New Ser. B. 1982; 14: 663-677Google Scholar), with concentrations ranging from 20 to 300 μM inhibited total protein synthesis by 90-98%. Cycloheximide inhibited the accumulation of αAmy7 and αAmy8 mRNAs regardless of the presence (Fig. 7A, lanes 3-7) or absence (Fig. 7A, lanes 10-14) of sucrose. In contrast, cycloheximide did not inhibit but instead effectively enhanced the accumulation of αAmy3 mRNA. In the absence of sucrose, cycloheximide significantly increased the level of αAmy3 mRNA independent of its dosage (Fig. 7A, lanes 10-14). In the presence of sucrose, cycloheximide increased the level of αAmy3 mRNA in a dose-dependent manner (Fig. 7A, lanes 3-7). Accumulation of actin mRNA was high in the presence of sucrose (Fig. 7A, lanes 1 and 2) and became low in the absence of sucrose (Fig. 7A, lanes 8 and 9). Cycloheximide also inhibited the accumulation of actin mRNA either in the presence (Fig. 7A, lanes 3-7) or absence (Fig. 7A, lanes 10-14) of sucrose but to a lesser extent as compared with the αAmy7 and αAmy8 mRNAs. Anisomycin, an inhibitor of transpeptidase (33Galling G. Encycl. Plant Physiol. New Ser. B. 1982; 14: 663-677Google Scholar), with concentration of 300 μM only 50% effective in inhibiting total protein synthesis, but the trends are exactly in the same direction as what was found when cycloheximide was used. Anisomycin promoted αAmy3 mRNA accumulation but suppressed αAmy7 and αAmy8 mRNA accumulation under both plus and minus sucrose conditions (Fig. 7B). Anisomycin also suppressed the actin mRNA accumulation under both plus and minus sucrose conditions. The suppression of αAmy8 mRNA accumulation in sucrose-starved cells by anisomycin (Fig. 7B, lane 4) was not as complete as that by cycloheximide (Fig. 7A, lanes 10-14), probably due to the less efficient inhibition of protein synthesis by anisomycin under our experimental condition. The availability of gene-specific probes corresponding to each of the eight α-amylase genes has enabled us to examine the abundance of mRNA encoding specific α-amylase isozymes. Although expression of the eight α-amylase genes increased in response to sucrose starvation (Fig. 3), levels of αAmy3 and αAmy8 mRNAs were significantly higher than those of other α-amylase genes and constituted approximately 90% of total α-amylase mRNA in cells starved for sucrose (Fig. 4). Therefore, expression of the α-amylase genes is coordinately up-regulated but in a distinct manner by sucrose starvation. A positive correlation between the transcription rates and the steady-state mRNA levels suggests that the transcriptional regulation plays an important role in the differential expression of α-amylase genes. Alteration in transcriptional activity suggests a model in which sugar-regulated transcription factors interact with cis-acting elements in the α-amylase gene promoters. Regions upstream from the TATA box of αAmy3 (RAmy3D) (22Huang N. Chandler J. Thomas B.R. Koizumi N. Rodriguez R.L. Plant Mol. Biol. 1993; 23: 737-747Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar) and αAmy8 (21Chan M.-T. Chao Y.-C. Yu S.-M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 17635-17641Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) share conserved sequences (34Huang N. Koizumi N. Reinl S. Rodriguez R.L. Nucleic Acids Res. 1990; 18: 7007-7014Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar) and possess the elements necessary for sugar repression. However, none of these sequence elements has been demonstrated to play a role in the regulation of rice α-amylase gene expression. Metabolic regulation of α-amylase gene expression by glucose has also been reported in other eukaryotes such as Drosophila melanogaster and Aspergillus oryzae. No significant sequence similarity is found between the Aspergillus (35Tsuchiya K. Tada S. Gomi K. Kitamoto K. Kumagai C. Tamura G. Biosci. Biotech. Biochem. 1992; 56: 1849-1853Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar) and the Drosophila (36Magoulas C. Bally-Cuif L. Loverre-Chyurlia A. Benkel B. Hickey D. Genetics. 1993; 134: 507-515Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) α-amylase gene promoters. However, some conserved sequences are found between the promoter region of either the Drosophila or the Aspergillus α-amylase gene with that of αAmy3. Under conditions in which transcription was inhibited, the half-lives of α-amylase mRNAs were longer in cells starved for sucrose than in cells provided with sucrose (Fig. 6), suggesting that increased mRNA stability contributed to an increase in α-amylase mRNA level in sucrose-starved cells. The αAmy7 mRNA seems inherently more stable because its half-life was 3-4 times longer than those of the αAmy3 and αAmy8 mRNAs, regardless of whether or not the cells were sucrose-starved. Compared with the αAmy7 mRNA, the αAmy3 and αAmy8 mRNAs were transcribed more rapidly in cells in response to sucrose starvation (Fig. 5) and were degraded more rapidly (Fig. 6) if cells were provided with sucrose. These results suggest that expression of αAmy3 and αAmy8 is under a stricter regulation and may encode isozymes essential for responses to changes of carbohydrate availability. It is unclear what mechanism directs the α-amylase mRNA to be degraded faster in cells provided with sucrose than in cells starved for sucrose. Regulated mRNA turnover has been described in detail in several vertebrate system (37Atwater J.A. Wisdom R. Verma I.M. Annu. Rev. Genet. 1990; 24: 519-541Crossref PubMed Scopus (212) Google Scholar), but the common regulatory mechanisms for mRNA turnover have not been found. Little is known about the processes responsible for the alteration of mRNA stability in plants, although mRNA stability can be affected by environmental conditions such as temperature (38Belanger F.C. Brodl M.R. Ho T.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1986; 83: 1354-1358Crossref PubMed Scopus (97) Google Scholar, 39Brodl M.R. Ho T.-H.D. Plant Physiol. 1991; 96: 1048-1052Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar) and illumination levels (40Shirley B.W. Meagher R.B. Nucleic Acids Res. 1990; 18: 3377-3385Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar, 41Thompson D.M. Meagher R.B. Nucleic Acids Res. 1990; 18: 3621-3629Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). The sucrose-induced acceleration of α-amylase mRNA degradation indicates that the trans-acting factor(s) of the mRNA decay system is likely subject to regulation. This may be α-amylase transcript-specific, since transcripts of the three α-amylase genes are affected similarly but the actin transcripts are not affected (Fig. 6). The differential stabilities among α-amylase transcripts, on the other hand, may be promoted by transcript-specific sequence elements and/or secondary structures. Many unstable transcripts in mammalian cells contain sequences within their 3′-UTRs that are AU-rich and contain one or more copies of the motif AUUUA (42Sachs A.B. Cell. 1993; 74: 413-421Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (774) Google Scholar). Unlike unstable mammalian transcripts, the 3′-UTRs of α-amylase mRNAs are not particularly AU-rich and do not contain multiple AUUUA sequences (Fig. 1). However, short AU-rich sequences are found throughout the 3′-UTRs of the α-amylase genes. Interestingly, although the α-amylase mRNA seems to be generally stabilized by starvation of cells (Fig. 6), the mechanism controlling the stability of different α-amylase mRNAs varied. Both the translation inhibitors cycloheximide and anisomycin enhanced the accumulation of αAmy3 mRNA regardless of whether or not the cells were provided with sucrose (Fig. 7). Such an effect of translation inhibitors was specific to αAmy3 mRNA, as the accumulation of αAmy7 and αAmy8 mRNA was suppressed by the inhibitors, even in cells starved for sucrose. Nuclear run-on transcription analyses demonstrated that cycloheximide did not significantly alter the transcription rates of αAmy3, αAmy7, and αAmy8 regardless of whether or not the cells were provided with sucrose (data not shown). Together, the results suggest that labile proteins are involved in the destabilization of αAmy3 mRNA and the stabilization of αAmy7 and αAmy8 mRNAs. In conclusion, the differential response of α-amylase genes to sugars provides a potential mechanism for altering the pattern of enzyme accumulation in response to changing carbohydrate status and sugar import. Although transcription of the α-amylase genes is induced by sucrose starvation, the dramatic increase in their steady-state mRNA levels requires stabilization of the mRNA as well. The combined processes may lead to more rapid and more marked shifts in the expression of α-amylase genes. Both processes may share similar upstream signaling pathways and contribute differently and in gene-specific manners to the regulation of the pool size of transcripts of individual α-amylase genes. We thank Dr. Yu-Chan Chao for critical review of this manuscript, Dr. Li-Fei Liu for providing the rice suspension cells, and Lin-Tze Yu for technical assistance.

We prepared a series of oligosaccharides from king crab cartilage chondroitin sulfate K after exhaustive digestion with testicular hyaluronidase, and determined the structures of four tetrasaccharides and a pentasaccharide by fast atom bombardment mass spectrometry, high performance liquid chromatography analysis of chondroitinase AC-II digests, and 500-MHz 1H NMR spectroscopy. The tetrasaccharides shared the common core structure GlcAβ1-3GalNAcβ1-4GlcAβ1-3GalNAc with various sulfation profiles. One structure was GlcAβ1-3GalNAc(4S)β1-4GlcAβ1-3GalNAc(4S), whereas three of them have the following hitherto unreported structures including a novel glucuronate 3-O-sulfate: GlcA(3S)β1-3GalNAc(4S)β1-4GlcAβ1-3GalNAc(4S), GlcAβ1-3GalNAc(4S)β1-4GlcA(3S)β1-3GalNAc(4S), and GlcA(3S)β1-3GalNAc(4S)β1-4GlcA(3S)β1-3GalNAc(4S), where 3S or 4S represents 3-O- or 4-O-sulfate, respectively. The structure of the pentasaccharide was determined as GlcA(3S)β1-3GalNAc(4S)β1-4GlcA(3S)β1- 3GalNAc(4S)β1-4GlcA. Chondroitinase ABC digestion of the tetrasaccharides with GlcA(3S) at the internal position destroyed the disaccharide unit containing GlcA(3S) derived from the reducing side and resulted in only the disaccharide unit from the non-reducing side. In contrast, these tetrasaccharides remained totally resistant to chondroitinase AC-II. The results indicated that it is necessary to reevaluate the disaccharide composition of chondroitin sulfate poly- or oligosaccharides purified from various biological sources, since they were usually determined after chondroitinase ABC digestion. It is probable that the structures containing GlcA(3S) would not have been detected. It is probable that the structures containing GlcA(3S) would not have been detected. It has become increasingly evident that the CS proteoglycans of cartilage are dynamic components that play several key roles in the normal physiology of cartilage tissues and regulate the biological processes such as cell migration and recognition, extracellular matrix deposition, and morphogenesis (for reviews, see 1Poole A.R. Biochem. J. 1986; 236: 1-14Crossref PubMed Scopus (378) Google Scholar, 2Fransson L.Å. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1987; 12: 406-411Abstract Full Text PDF Scopus (185) Google Scholar, 3Ruoslahti E. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 13369-13372Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Because many of their functions are associated with the glycosaminoglycan moieties (1Poole A.R. Biochem. J. 1986; 236: 1-14Crossref PubMed Scopus (378) Google Scholar), the structure of the CS chains is of considerable interest. However, the complexity and diversity of the structures have prevented detailed structural analysis. chondroitin sulfate chondroitin sulfate A, D, E, or K 2-aminobenzamide dermatan sulfate fast atom bombardment-mass spectrometry N-acetyl-D-galactosamine D-glucuronic acid 4,5-unsaturated hexuronic acid or 4-deoxy-α-L-threo-hex-4-ene-pyranosyluronic acid hexuronic acid N-acetylhexosamine high performance liquid chromatography national formulary unit Δ4,5HexAα1-3GalNAc Δ4,5HexAα1-3GalNAc(6-O-sulfate) Δ4,5HexAα1-3GalNAc(4-O-sulfate) GlcAβ1-3GalNAc(4-O-sulfate) Δ4,5HexA(2-O-sulfate)α1-3GalNAc(6-O-sulfate) Δ4,5HexAα1-3GalNAc(4,6-O-disulfate) Δ4,5HexA(2-O-sulfate)α1-3GalNAc(4,6-O-disulfate) chondro-4-O-sulfatase chondro-6-O-sulfatase ΔHexA, GalNAc, GlcA, 2-O-sulfate, 3-O-sulfate, 4-O-sulfate, and 6-O-sulfate, respectively. The structural complexity of CS chains arises from an extensive series of modifications of a non-sulfated precursor with the structure (−4GlcAβ1-3GalNAcβ1-)n. These modifications are achieved by specific modifying enzymes such as sulfotransferases and epimerases that mature the CS chains. Thus, the controlled expression of these biosynthetic enzymes is thought to be regulating factors in the elaboration of various CS isoforms. The CS chains from the cartilages of various animal species also have highly variable sulfation profiles, incorporating both oversulfated and non-sulfated structures, and they have been roughly classified into types A, B, C, D, E, and K (4Meyer K. Fed. Proc. 1958; 17: 1075-1077PubMed Google Scholar, 5Suzuki S. J. Biol. Chem. 1960; 235: 3580-3588Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar, 6Suzuki S. Saito H. Yamagata T. Anno K. Seno N. Kawai Y. Furuhashi T. J. Biol. Chem. 1968; 243: 1543-1550Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 7Seno N. Murakami K. Carbohydr. Res. 1982; 103: 190-194Crossref Scopus (29) Google Scholar). Preliminary chemical analyses have indicated that unlike the CS from many other cartilages, CSK isolated from that of the king crab seems to contain 3-O-sulfated GlcA residues (7Seno N. Murakami K. Carbohydr. Res. 1982; 103: 190-194Crossref Scopus (29) Google Scholar). The 3-O-sulfated GlcA was later found in sea cucumber CS as well (8Vieira R.P. Mulloy B. Mourão P.A.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 13530-13536Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This novel structure forms a unique carbohydrate epitope on glycoproteins and glycolipids in nervous tissues, which is recognized by the HNK-1 monoclonal antibody (9Chou D.K.H. Ilyas A.A. Evans J.E. Costello C. Quarles R.H. Jungalwala F.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 11717-11725Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Immunoblots of the CS proteoglycans of the brain as well as a number of nervous tissue glycoproteins are intensely stained by the HNK-1 antibody (10Gowda D.C. Margolis R.U. Margolis R.K. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 4468-4474Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar). We have been conducting systematic structural studies of oversulfated CS from the cartilages of various animal species, including shark and squid (11Sugahara K. Shigeno K. Masuda M. Fujii N. Kurosaka A. Takeda K. Carbohydr. Res. 1994; 255: 145-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar, 12Sugahara K. Takemura Y. Sugiura M. Kohno Y. Yoshida K. Takeda K. Khoo K.H. Morris H.R. Dell A. Carbohydr. Res. 1994; 255: 165-182Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar, 13Sugahara K. Tanaka Y. Yamada S. Glycoconjugate J. 1996; 13: 609-619Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). In this study, four tetrasaccharides and a pentasaccharide from the CSK of king crab cartilage were isolated after hyaluronidase digestion. The analysis by enzymatic degradation and 500-MHz 1H NMR spectroscopy unambiguously demonstrated 3-O-sulfated GlcA residues in these oligosaccharides. Furthermore, an unexpected degradation of these oligosaccharides by the enzymatic action of chondroitinase ABC was revealed. Preliminary results have been reported in abstract form (14Sugahara, K., Tanaka, Y., Yamada, S., Kitagawa, H., Seno, N., (1994) Abstract of International Symposium on Cartilage Metabolism, Nov. 16-18, 1994, Osaka, pp. 12-13, Abstr. 16A-2.Google Scholar). CSK peptide preparation was purified from king crab cartilage as reported (15Seno N. Yamashiro S. Anno K. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1974; 343: 423-426Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar). Six unsaturated standard CS disaccharides, chondroitinases ABC (EC 4.2.2.4) and AC-II (EC 4.2.2.5), chondro-4-O-sulfatase (EC 3.1.6.9, abbreviated as CS-4-sulfatase), and chondro-6-O-sulfatase (EC 3.1.6.10, abbreviated as CS-6-sulfatase) were purchased from Seikagaku Corp., Tokyo, Japan. Sheep testicular hyaluronidase (EC 3.2.1.35) was obtained from Sigma. Bio-Gel P-10 and Sephadex G-25 (fine) were obtained from Bio-Rad and Pharmacia Biotech Inc., respectively. The CSK peptide preparation (20 mg) was digested with 2 mg (approximately 3000 NFU) of sheep testicular hyaluronidase in a total volume of 2.0 ml of 50 mM sodium phosphate buffer, pH 6.0, containing 150 mM NaCl (1 NFU corresponds to the amount of the enzyme that hydrolyzes 74 μg of hyaluronate/min) (16Poh C.H. Yuen R. Chung M.C.M. Khoo H.E. Comp. Biochem. Physiol. 1992; 101B: 159-163Google Scholar, 17Sugahara K. Yamada S. Sugiura M. Takeda K. Yuen R. Khoo H.E. Poh C.H. Biochem. J. 1992; 283: 99-104Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). Digestion proceeded at 37°C for 18 h, after which an additional 1 mg (1500 NFU) of the enzyme was added and the incubation was continued for 7 h to complete the digestion. Thereafter, the digest was mixed with 0.42 ml of 30% trichloroacetic acid and centrifuged. The precipitate was washed with 0.5 ml of 5% trichloroacetic acid. The combined supernatant obtained from trichloroacetic acid precipitation was extracted with ether, the aqueous phase was neutralized with 1 M Na2CO3, and the sample was then applied to a Bio-Gel P-10 column (1.6 × 95 cm) using 1 M NaCl, 10% ethanol as the eluent. Eluates were monitored by the absorbance at 210 nm, which is attributable mainly to the N-acetyl group of GalNAc. Tetra-, hexa-, and octasaccharide fractions were pooled (Fig. 2), concentrated, desalted through a column (1.5 × 46 cm) of Sephadex G-25 (fine), and lyophilized. The smallest size fraction, which was presumed to contain tetrasaccharides, was subfractionated by HPLC on an amine-bound silica column as described for unsaturated CS tetrasaccharides (11Sugahara K. Shigeno K. Masuda M. Fujii N. Kurosaka A. Takeda K. Carbohydr. Res. 1994; 255: 145-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar). The eluates were monitored by absorbance at 210 nm. Each peak was purified by rechromatography under the same conditions as the first step and desalted as described above. Each peak was quantified by the carbazole method, using GlcA as a standard (18Bitter M. Muir H. Anal. Biochem. 1962; 4: 330-334Crossref PubMed Scopus (5192) Google Scholar). The homogeneity of each fraction was judged by capillary electrophoresis (19Sugahara K. Tohno-oka R. Yamada S. Khoo K.H. Morris H.R. Dell A. Glycobiology. 1994; 4: 535-544Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar) as well as by HPLC. A new fused silica capillary (60 cm total length, 75 μm internal diameter; Millipore Corp.) was activated by sequential washes with 0.1 M sodium hydroxide, distilled water, and 25 mM sodium phosphate buffer, pH 3.0, before use. The electrophoretic fractions were detected by absorption at 185 nm. Samples (1 nmol/10 μl), prepared in distilled water, were injected using hydrostatic pressure to give a total injected volume of 24 nl. The electrophoresis was performed using constant voltage of 15 kV for a period of 20 min. The polarity of the power supply was negative. Oligosaccharides (2 nmol as GlcA) were digested using 5 mIU each of chondroitinases ABC or AC-II, or 50 mIU of CS-6-sulfatase as described (11Sugahara K. Shigeno K. Masuda M. Fujii N. Kurosaka A. Takeda K. Carbohydr. Res. 1994; 255: 145-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar). CS-4-sulfatase digestion proceeded under either standard or harsh incubation conditions; the former or the latter used 20 or 50 mIU of the enzyme for 10 or 60 min, respectively, basically as described (11Sugahara K. Shigeno K. Masuda M. Fujii N. Kurosaka A. Takeda K. Carbohydr. Res. 1994; 255: 145-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar). Reactions were terminated by boiling for 1 min, and the reaction mixture was analyzed by HPLC as reported (11Sugahara K. Shigeno K. Masuda M. Fujii N. Kurosaka A. Takeda K. Carbohydr. Res. 1994; 255: 145-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar). Eluates were monitored by absorption at both 210 and 232 nm. The sugar and sulfate compositions of oligosaccharides were determined by FAB-MS. FAB mass spectra of the oligosaccharide samples were obtained using a VG Analytical ZAB-2SE 2FPD mass spectrometer fitted with a cesium ion gun operated at 20-25 kV. Data were acquired and processed using the VG Analytical Opus software. Monothioglycerol was used as the matrix. 1H NMR spectra of the oligosaccharides were measured on a Varian-500 at a probe temperature of 15, 26, 40, or 60°C as reported (11Sugahara K. Shigeno K. Masuda M. Fujii N. Kurosaka A. Takeda K. Carbohydr. Res. 1994; 255: 145-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar, 13Sugahara K. Tanaka Y. Yamada S. Glycoconjugate J. 1996; 13: 609-619Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). Chemical shifts are given relative to sodium 4,4-dimethyl-4-silapentane-1-sulfonate, but were actually measured indirectly, relative to acetone (δ 2.225) in 2H2O (20Vliegenthart J.F.G. Dorland L. Van Halbeek H. Adv. Carbohydr. Chem. Biochem. 1983; 41: 209-374Crossref Scopus (796) Google Scholar). Oligosaccharides for NMR analysis were repeatedly exchanged in 2H2O with intermediate lyophilization. The oligosaccharide fractions 3, 4, or 5 (0.5 nmol each) were first digested using 5 mIU of chondroitinase ABC as described (11Sugahara K. Shigeno K. Masuda M. Fujii N. Kurosaka A. Takeda K. Carbohydr. Res. 1994; 255: 145-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar), and evaporated to dryness. The digests were derivatized with 2-AB according to the manufacturer's instructions (Signal™ labeling kit, Oxford GlycoSystems). The labeled disaccharides were analyzed by HPLC on an amine-bound silica PA03 column (4.6 × 250 mm; YMC Co., Kyoto, Japan). The HPLC was performed in an LC-10AS system (Shimadzu Co., Kyoto, Japan) using a linear gradient from 16 to 798 mM NaH2PO4 over a 60-min period at a flow rate of 1.0 ml/min at room temperature. Samples prepared as described above were diluted to contain 50 pmol of disaccharides in 200 μl of 16 mM NaH2PO4. Eluates were monitored using an RF-535 fluorometric detector (Shimadzu Co.) with excitation and emission wavelengths of 330 and 420 nm, respectively. The CSK peptide preparation (7.1 nmol as GlcA) was digested using 10 mIU of chondroitinase ABC as described (11Sugahara K. Shigeno K. Masuda M. Fujii N. Kurosaka A. Takeda K. Carbohydr. Res. 1994; 255: 145-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar). Reactions were terminated by boiling for 1 min, and half of the reaction mixture was analyzed by HPLC as reported (11Sugahara K. Shigeno K. Masuda M. Fujii N. Kurosaka A. Takeda K. Carbohydr. Res. 1994; 255: 145-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar). Eluates were monitored by absorption at both 210 and 232 nm. The CSK peptide preparation purified from king crab cartilage was digested with sheep testicular hyaluronidase, as CSK was largely resistant to the enzymatic action of chondroitinases ABC and AC. As shown in Fig. 1, it was readily digested by hyaluronidase and was more susceptible than the other CS isoforms. The digest was fractionated by gel filtration on a column of Bio-Gel P-10. Three peaks were observed when monitored by absorbance at 210 nm caused primarily by N-acetyl groups and they were assigned as tetra-, hexa-, and octasaccharide fractions as indicated in Fig. 2. The amounts of these fractions obtained from 20 mg of CSK were approximately 4.9, 13, and 1.7 mg, respectively. The elution profile was significantly different from that reported for a commercial CSD preparation (13Sugahara K. Tanaka Y. Yamada S. Glycoconjugate J. 1996; 13: 609-619Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar), in that there were no fragments larger than octasaccharides among the CSK degradation products. The large peak at around fraction number 80 was attributable to the buffer salts. The tetrasaccharide fraction was subfractionated into Fractions 1-5 by HPLC on an amine-bound silica column. As shown in Fig. 3, Fractions 1 and 2 were eluted at the positions of authentic saturated tetrasaccharides with two and three sulfate groups, respectively, whereas Fractions 3-5 were eluted at higher salt concentrations. They were further purified by rechromatography to apparent homogeneity, as judged by HPLC and capillary electrophoresis (data not shown), after which their structures were analyzed as described below. In the negative ion mode FAB spectrum, alkali-metal-attached molecular ions of the type [M − (x+1)H + xNa]− (M represents the fully protonated acid forms of oligosaccharides) were preferentially observed. The assignments of the molecular ion signals afforded by each of the analyzed fractions are listed in Table I. The molecular ion signal clusters at m/z 935, 957, 979, and 1001 afforded by Fraction 1 corresponded respectively to [M − H]−, [M + Na − 2H]−, [M + 2Na − 3H]−, and [M + 3Na − 4H]− of a disulfated saturated tetrasaccharide HexA2HexNAc2(OSO3H)2 (data not shown). Fractions 2 and 3 afforded similar FAB-MS data, suggesting that they are isomers of identical composition. The samples yielded molecular ion signals at m/z 1015, 1037, 1059, and 1081, corresponding to [M − H]−, [M + Na − 2H]−, [M + 2Na − 3H]−, and [M + 3Na − 4H]−, respectively, of a trisulfated saturated tetrasaccharide HexA2HexNAc2(OSO3H)3 (Fig. 4A). As shown in Fig. 4B, Fraction 4 afforded molecular ion signals at m/z 1095, 1117, 1139, and 1161, corresponding to [M − H]−, [M + Na − 2H]−, [M + 2Na − 3H]−, and [M + 3Na − 4H]−, respectively, of a tetrasulfated saturated tetrasaccharide HexA2HexNAc2(OSO3H)4. Fraction 5 afforded molecular ion signals at m/z 1271, 1293, 1315, 1337, and 1359, corresponding to [M − H]−, [M + Na − 2H]−, [M + 2Na − 3H]−, [M + 3Na − 4H]−, and [M + 4Na − 5H]−, respectively, of a tetrasulfated saturated pentasaccharide HexA3HexNAc2(OSO3H)4 (Fig. 4C). As shown in Fig. 3, Fraction 1 was eluted upon HPLC at the position of the authentic disulfated tetrasaccharide GlcAβ1-3GalNAc(4S)β1-4GlcAβ1-3GalNAc(4S), where 4S denotes 4-O-sulfate (Fraction 2 derived from shark cartilage CSD in 13Sugahara K. Tanaka Y. Yamada S. Glycoconjugate J. 1996; 13: 609-619Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). The disaccharide analysis of this fraction, which was carried out by exhaustive chondroitinase AC-II digestion followed by HPLC on an amine-bound silica column, gave rise to a major peak at the elution position of ΔHexAα1-3GalNAc(4S) (ΔDi-4S) and a minor one at the position of the saturated disaccharide GlcAβ1-3GalNAc(4S) (Di-4S) slightly ahead of ΔDi-4S when monitored by the absorbance at 210 nm (data not shown). Only the major peak absorbed at 232 nm. The data are summarized in Table II with those obtained from the other fractions. Thus, the major and the minor peaks detected by absorbance at 210 nm were judged to be due to an unsaturated and a saturated disaccharide derived from the reducing and non-reducing side of the parent tetrasaccharide, respectively, as discussed (13Sugahara K. Tanaka Y. Yamada S. Glycoconjugate J. 1996; 13: 609-619Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). The successive digestion of Fraction 2 with chondroitinase AC-II and CS-4-sulfatase yielded a major peak at the elution position of ΔDi-0S and a minor one shortly before the position of ΔHexAα1-3GalNAc(6S) (ΔDi-6S) (data not shown). These results summarized in Table II indicated that the compound in Fraction 2 is a trisulfated tetrasaccharide composed of a Di-4S unit on the reducing side and an unidentified disulfated disaccharide unit with GalNAc(4S) on the non-reducing side, namely GlcA(S)β1-3GalNAc(4S)β1-4GlcAβ1-3GalNAc(4S), where S represents a sulfate group at an unidentified position. Since Fraction 3 was resistant to chondroitinase AC-II, it was digested with chondroitinase ABC and the products were analyzed in the above HPLC system. HPLC analysis of the chondroitinase ABC digest gave rise to a single peak at the position of authentic Di-4S, slightly ahead of ΔDi-4S when monitored by absorbance at 210 nm (Table II). No peak was detected when monitored by the absorbance at 232 nm. The peak of Fraction 3 shifted on HPLC by 10 min upon CS-4-sulfatase digestion under the standard and harsh incubation conditions (see “Experimental Procedures”) (data not shown), indicating that it contained at least one sulfate group on C-4 of a GalNAc residue. Fraction 3 was resistant to CS-6-sulfatase. This enzyme specifically attacks GalNAc(6S) at the reducing end of unsaturated CS oligosaccharides (11Sugahara K. Shigeno K. Masuda M. Fujii N. Kurosaka A. Takeda K. Carbohydr. Res. 1994; 255: 145-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar, 12Sugahara K. Takemura Y. Sugiura M. Kohno Y. Yoshida K. Takeda K. Khoo K.H. Morris H.R. Dell A. Carbohydr. Res. 1994; 255: 165-182Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). We also showed that the enzyme digested saturated CS tetra- and hexasaccharides as well. 2Nadanaka, S., and Sugahara, K., Glycobiology, in press. In contrast, CS-4-sulfatase preferentially removes a sulfate group from GalNAc(4S) at the reducing terminus of CS oligosaccharides under the standard incubation conditions but also releases sulfate groups from internal GalNAc(4S) residues under harsh conditions (11Sugahara K. Shigeno K. Masuda M. Fujii N. Kurosaka A. Takeda K. Carbohydr. Res. 1994; 255: 145-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar) (see “Experimental Procedures”). The susceptibility to CS-4-sulfatase and the insusceptibility to CS-6-sulfatase suggested that the reducing GalNAc is monosulfated only at its C-4 position, and that the third sulfate group is probably on the internal GlcA residue, since the tetrasaccharide was resistant to chondroitinase AC-II (7Seno N. Murakami K. Carbohydr. Res. 1982; 103: 190-194Crossref Scopus (29) Google Scholar, 8Vieira R.P. Mulloy B. Mourão P.A.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 13530-13536Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Thus, the compound in Fraction 3 was assumed to be a trisulfated tetrasaccharide composed of a Di-4S unit on the non-reducing side and an unidentified disulfated disaccharide unit including the structure GlcAβ1-3GalNAc(4S) on the reducing side, possibly GlcAβ1-3GalNAc(4S)β1-4GlcA(S) β1-3GalNAc(4S). Since Fraction 4 was also resistant to chondroitinase AC-II, we digested it with chondroitinase ABC followed by HPLC analysis as described above. The digest gave rise to a single HPLC peak at a position between ΔDi-diSD and ΔDi-diSE when monitored by the absorbance at 210 nm (Fig. 5B). There was no peak when monitored by the absorbance at 232 nm (Fig. 5C and Table II). One sulfate group was lost upon CS-4-sulfatase digestion of Fraction 4 under the standard and harsh incubation conditions (see “Experimental Procedures”) as judged by HPLC (data not shown). These results and those from FAB-MS (Table I) indicated that the compound in Fraction 4 is a tetrasulfated tetrasaccharide composed of an unidentified disulfated disaccharide unit on the non-reducing side and an unidentified disulfated disaccharide unit including the GlcAβ1-3GalNAc(4S) structure on the reducing side; i.e. {disulfated (GlcAβ1- 3GalNAc)}β1-4GlcA(S)β1-3GalNAc(4S). Since Fraction 5 was also resistant to chondroitinase AC-II, we digested it with chondroitinase ABC and analyzed the products by HPLC as described above. Chondroitinase ABC digestion resulted in two discrete peaks, one at the position of authentic Di-4S and the other between ΔDi-diSD and ΔDi-diSE when monitored by the absorbance at 210 nm (Table II). No peak was detected unexpectedly at 232 nm (data not shown). One sulfate group of the parent compound in Fraction 5 was lost upon CS-4-sulfatase digestion under the harsh incubation conditions (see “Experimental Procedures”) as judged by HPLC (data not shown). The motile activities of the small, single-headed class I myosins (myosin I) from the lower eukaryotes Acanthamoeba and Dictyostelium are activated by phosphorylation of a single serine or threonine residue in the head domain of the heavy chain. Recently, we purified a myosin I heavy chain kinase (MIHCK) from Dictyostelium based on its ability to activate the Dictyostelium myosin ID isozyme (Lee, S.-F., and Côté, G. P. (1995) J. Biol. Chem. 270, 11776-11782). The complete sequence of the Dictyostelium MIHCK has now been determined, revealing a protein of 98 kDa that is composed of an amino-terminal domain rich in proline, glutamine, and serine, a putative Cdc42/Rac binding motif, and a carboxyl-terminal kinase catalytic domain. MIHCK shares significant sequence identity with the Saccharomyces cerevisiae Ste20p kinase and the mammalian p21-activated kinase. Gel overlay assays and affinity chromatography experiments showed that MIHCK interacted with GTPγS (guanosine 5′-3-O-(thiotriphosphate))-labeled Cdc42 and Rac1 but not RhoA. In the presence of GTPγS-Rac1 MIHCK autophosphorylation increased from 1 to 9 mol of phosphate/mol, and the rate of Dictyostelium myosin ID phosphorylation was stimulated 10-fold. MIHCK may therefore provide a direct link between Cdc42/Rac signaling pathways and motile processes driven by myosin I molecules. Recently, we purified a myosin I heavy chain kinase (MIHCK) from Dictyostelium based on its ability to activate the Dictyostelium myosin ID isozyme (Lee, S.-F., and Côté, G. P. (1995) J. Biol. Chem. 270, 11776-11782). The complete sequence of the Dictyostelium MIHCK has now been determined, revealing a protein of 98 kDa that is composed of an amino-terminal domain rich in proline, glutamine, and serine, a putative Cdc42/Rac binding motif, and a carboxyl-terminal kinase catalytic domain. MIHCK shares significant sequence identity with the Saccharomyces cerevisiae Ste20p kinase and the mammalian p21-activated kinase. Gel overlay assays and affinity chromatography experiments showed that MIHCK interacted with GTPγS (guanosine 5′-3-O-(thiotriphosphate))-labeled Cdc42 and Rac1 but not RhoA. In the presence of GTPγS-Rac1 MIHCK autophosphorylation increased from 1 to 9 mol of phosphate/mol, and the rate of Dictyostelium myosin ID phosphorylation was stimulated 10-fold. MIHCK may therefore provide a direct link between Cdc42/Rac signaling pathways and motile processes driven by myosin I molecules.

Many eukaryotic cell surface proteins are bound to the membrane via a glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor. Assembly of the GPI anchor precursor is a sequential addition of components to phosphatidylinositol (PI) in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). The first step is the transfer of N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) to PI from UDP-GlcNAc to generate GlcNAc-PI. This simple step, however, is regulated by at least three genes because in both mammals and yeasts, there are three mutants of different complementation classes. To clarify this complexity, we analyzed the products of two cloned human genes, PIG-A and PIG-H. Here we demonstrate 1) that PIG-A is an ER transmembrane protein with a large cytoplasmic domain that has homology to a bacterial GlcNAc transferase and a small lumenal domain; 2) that PIG-H is a cytoplasmically oriented, ER-associated protein; and 3) that they form a protein complex. We also show that part of the small lumenal domain of PIG-A plays an essential functional role in targeting itself to the rough ER. Taken together with the cytoplasmic orientation of GlcNAc-PI, these results indicated that PIG-A and PIG-H are subunits of the GPI GlcNAc transferase that transfers GlcNAc to PI on the cytoplasmic side of the ER. To clarify this complexity, we analyzed the products of two cloned human genes, PIG-A and PIG-H. Here we demonstrate 1) that PIG-A is an ER transmembrane protein with a large cytoplasmic domain that has homology to a bacterial GlcNAc transferase and a small lumenal domain; 2) that PIG-H is a cytoplasmically oriented, ER-associated protein; and 3) that they form a protein complex. We also show that part of the small lumenal domain of PIG-A plays an essential functional role in targeting itself to the rough ER. Taken together with the cytoplasmic orientation of GlcNAc-PI, these results indicated that PIG-A and PIG-H are subunits of the GPI GlcNAc transferase that transfers GlcNAc to PI on the cytoplasmic side of the ER.
