Boerboom D. Westphal H. Tremblay L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 3030-3040Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar). However, since full-length cDNA probes were used for Northern blot or dot blot analysis, in these studies it is not known whether one form or both the major forms are induced by mitogens. Using quantitative PCR methods, we observed that both PTP-S2 and PTP-S4 are induced during rat liver regeneration after partial hepatectomy (Fig. 7). Relative quantitation of these isoforms showed that PTP-S4 was induced somewhat more than PTP-S2 isoform. As a control, expression of GAPDH mRNA was also analyzed during liver regeneration, which showed a small increase (about 3-4-fold) over control liver. Increase in level of GAPDH mRNA during liver regeneration has been reported earlier (31Loyer P. Glaise D. Cariou S. Baffet G. Meijer L. Guguen-Guillouzo C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 2491-2500Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). When PTP-S2 and PTP-S4 mRNA levels were normalized to GAPDH mRNA it was found that both PTP-S2 and PTP-S4 still showed 5-6-fold increase in their levels after 6 h of partial hepatectomy. To our knowledge, PTP-S is the first PTP that has been shown to generate, by alternative splicing, two forms with inherent differences in their substrate specificity. These forms differ in their enzymatic activity toward phosphorylated protein substrates but not with pNPP as substrate, suggesting thereby that the amino acid residues in the non-catalytic domain are important in determining the interaction with polypeptide substrates even in vitro. This conclusion is also supported by the observation that deletion of C-terminal amino acids of PTP-S2 results in much higher activity toward poly(Glu4,Tyr1) as substrate, but the activity toward MBP does not increase. Previously it has been reported that alternative splicing generates two forms of a PTP in Drosophila (dPTP61F), which show different subcellular location (nucleus and mitochondria) but show similar phosphatase activity as judged by the use of pNPP as substrate (14McLaughlin S. Dixon J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 6839-6842Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The enzyme activity of these forms was not compared using polypeptide substrates. The most unexpected observation we have made is that PTP-S4 does not interact with nonspecific DNA in vitro although it has the DNA binding domain that is present in PTP-S2. The DNA binding potential of PTP-S4 is revealed by deleting the C-terminal 34 amino acids. Our results suggest that the C-terminal 34 amino acids are likely to fold in such a manner that it would make the basic DNA binding domain of PTP-S4 inaccessible for interaction with nonspecific DNA. This “masking” of basic domain, physically or functionally, may allow interaction of a basic substrate (such as MBP) with the acidic domain that precedes the basic domain. Such a model would predict that the deletion of basic domain of PTP-S2 would increase enzyme activity with MBP as substrate but not with poly(Glu4,Tyr1). However, deletion of basic domain of PTP-S2 resulted in an enzyme with increased activity toward poly(Glu4,Tyr1) but not with MBP. Therefore, it seems possible that the C-terminal 34 amino acid domain may be directly involved in the binding of the basic substrate (e.g. by providing contact points), in addition to masking the basic domain of PTP-S4. PTP-S2 localizes in the cell nucleus largely in association with chromatin, although a small amount is associated with the nuclear matrix. The DNA binding property of PTP-S2 suggests that its association with chromatin may be through direct interaction with DNA. The human equivalent of PTP-S2, p45TC, was found to be a nuclear protein by immunostaining (23Lorenzen J.A. Dadabay C.Y. Fischer E.H. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 131: 631-643Crossref PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar). Upon cell lysis, however, p45TC fractionates as a soluble protein. This is likely to be due to the use of hypotonic buffer with EDTA (without divalent ions) for cell lysis; under these conditions, nuclei are not likely to be intact (23Lorenzen J.A. Dadabay C.Y. Fischer E.H. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 131: 631-643Crossref PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar). Within the nucleus, PTP-S2 shows more prominent nucleolar staining in transfected cells. A similar pattern has been observed for the mouse homolog (22Tillmann U. Wagner J. Boerboom D. Westphal H. Tremblay L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 3030-3040Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar). The human homolog of PTP-S2, however, showed no staining in the nucleolus (23Lorenzen J.A. Dadabay C.Y. Fischer E.H. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 131: 631-643Crossref PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar). We observed that untransfected HeLa cells stained with a polyclonal anti-PTP-S antibody showed prominent nuclear staining, but the nucleolus was not stained (data not shown). This suggests that a signal for nucleolar localization may be present in rat and mouse PTP-S2, but it may be nonfunctional (or absent) in the human homolog. PTP-S4 localizes mainly in the cytoplasmic and nuclear membranes. Its staining pattern is very similar to that of human T-cell phosphatase (p48TC), which is located in the endoplasmic reticulum and nuclear membrane (23Lorenzen J.A. Dadabay C.Y. Fischer E.H. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 131: 631-643Crossref PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar, 32Faure R. Posner B.I. Glia. 1993; 9: 311-314Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). Another related phosphatase, PTP-1B, has been shown to be located in the endoplasmic reticulum (2Frangioni J.V. Beahm P.H. Shifrin V. Jost C.A. Neel B.G. Cell. 1992; 68: 545-560Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (508) Google Scholar, 6Woodford-Thomas T.A. Rhodes J.D. Dixon J.E. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 117: 401-414Crossref PubMed Scopus (154) Google Scholar). The staining pattern of PTP-S4 differs from that of PTP-1B in having prominent staining of nuclear membrane. Interaction of PTP-S4 with nuclear matrix is much stronger than that of PTP-S2 and requires the C-terminal 34-amino acid domain. The association of PTP-S4 with nuclear matrix is of particular interest, since this subnuclear structure is involved in several nuclear functions such as DNA replication, transcription, etc. (33Pienta K.J. Partin A.W. Coffey D.S. Cancer Res. 1989; 49: 2525-2532PubMed Google Scholar). Recently tyrosine kinase activity has been found in the nuclear matrix, which shows cell cycle-dependent changes that are maximal during G1/S transition (27Radha V. Nambirajan S. Swarup G. Eur. J. Biochem. 1996; 236: 352-359Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). One of the tyrosine kinases found tightly associated with nuclear matrix is Lyn, a member of the Src family (27Radha V. Nambirajan S. Swarup G. Eur. J. Biochem. 1996; 236: 352-359Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). We have shown previously that PTP-S mRNA levels increase upon mitogenic stimulation of T lymphocytes and that the increase is due to post-transcriptional stabilization of mRNA in the stimulated cells (20Rajendrakumar G.V. Radha V. Swarup G. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1216: 205-212Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar). PTP-S mRNA was superinduced in lymphocytes in the presence of cycloheximide (20Rajendrakumar G.V. Radha V. Swarup G. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1216: 205-212Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar). Both the major isoforms, PTP-S2 and PTP-S4, are induced upon mitogenic stimulation of liver cells (this study). The timing of induction of PTP-S2 and PTP-S4 suggests that these are delayed early genes. Higashitsuji et al. (34Higashitsuji H. Arii S. Furutani M. Imamura M. Kaneko Y. Takenawa J. Nakayama H. Fugita J. Oncogene. 1995; 10: 407-414PubMed Google Scholar) have shown that during mouse liver regeneration, PTP-PEST and PTP-RL9 (a novel intracellular phosphatase) are induced to peak levels at 6 h after partial hepatectomy, while another enzyme, PTP-RL10, increases and peaks only after the first round of cell division, i.e. 48-72 h. PRL-1, MKP-1, Pac-1, and VH1 family members are examples of tyrosine and dual specificity phosphatases that behave as immediate early genes upon mitogenic stimulation (35Diamond R.H. Cressman D.E. Laz T.M. Abrams C.S. Taub R. Mol. Cell Biol. 1994; 14: 3752-3762Crossref PubMed Scopus (248) Google Scholar, 36Rohan P.J. Davis P. Maskaluk C.A. Kearns M. Krutzsch H. Siebenlist U. Kelly K. Science. 1993; 259: 1763-1766Crossref PubMed Scopus (264) Google Scholar, 37Kwak S.P. Dixon J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 1156-1160Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar). Upon growth factor stimulation of quiescent cells, one of the isoforms of PTP-1B is induced, reaching peak levels by late G1, but the generation of this isoform requires protein synthesis (38Shifrin V.I. Neel B.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25376-25384Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Thus, different PTPs show distinct pattern of induction in response to mitogenic stimulation, but their role in cell proliferation remains to be elucidated. We thank Drs. D. Balasubramanian and U. Srinivas for critical reading of the manuscript.

Acanthamoeba myosin I heavy chain (MIHC) kinase is a monomeric 97-kDa protein that is activated by binding to acidic phospholipids or by autophosphorylation. Activation by phospholipids is inhibited by Ca2+-calmodulin. In the accompanying paper (Brzeska, H., Martin, B., and Korn, E. D. (1996) J. Biol. Chem. 271, 27049-27055), we identified the catalytic domain as the COOH-terminal 35 kDa produced by trypsin digestion of phosphorylated MIHC kinase. In this paper, we report the cloning and sequencing of the corresponding cDNA and expression of fully active catalytic domain. The expressed catalytic domain has substrate specificity similar to that of native kinase and resistance to trypsin similar to that of fully phosphorylated MIHC kinase. MIHC kinase catalytic domain has only 25% sequence identity to the catalytic domain of protein kinase A and similarly low sequence identity to the catalytic domains of protein kinase C- and calmodulin-dependent kinases, but 50% sequence identity and 70% similarity to the p21-activated kinase (PAK) and STE20 family of kinases. This suggests that MIHC kinase is (at least) evolutionarily related to the PAK family, whose activities are regulated by small GTP-binding proteins. The homology includes the presence of a potential MIHC kinase autophosphorylation site as well as conserved Tyr and Ser/Thr residues in the region corresponding to the P+1 loop of protein kinase A. A synthetic peptide corresponding to this region of MIHC kinase is phosphorylated by both the expressed catalytic domain and native MIHC kinase. Acanthamoeba myosin I heavy chain (MIHC) kinase is a monomeric 97-kDa protein that is activated by binding to acidic phospholipids or by autophosphorylation. Activation by phospholipids is inhibited by Ca2+-calmodulin. In the accompanying paper (Brzeska, H., Martin, B., and Korn, E. D. (1996) J. Biol. Chem. 271, 27049-27055), we identified the catalytic domain as the COOH-terminal 35 kDa produced by trypsin digestion of phosphorylated MIHC kinase. In this paper, we report the cloning and sequencing of the corresponding cDNA and expression of fully active catalytic domain. The expressed catalytic domain has substrate specificity similar to that of native kinase and resistance to trypsin similar to that of fully phosphorylated MIHC kinase. MIHC kinase catalytic domain has only 25% sequence identity to the catalytic domain of protein kinase A and similarly low sequence identity to the catalytic domains of protein kinase C- and calmodulin-dependent kinases, but 50% sequence identity and 70% similarity to the p21-activated kinase (PAK) and STE20 family of kinases. This suggests that MIHC kinase is (at least) evolutionarily related to the PAK family, whose activities are regulated by small GTP-binding proteins. The homology includes the presence of a potential MIHC kinase autophosphorylation site as well as conserved Tyr and Ser/Thr residues in the region corresponding to the P+1 loop of protein kinase A. A synthetic peptide corresponding to this region of MIHC kinase is phosphorylated by both the expressed catalytic domain and native MIHC kinase.

Aggregation of the high affinity receptor for IgE (FcϵRI) on the mucosal mast cell line, RBL-2H3, results in the rapid and persistent tyrosine phosphorylation of Vav. Immunoprecipitation of Vav from activated cells revealed co-immunoprecipitated phosphoproteins of molecular weights identical to the FcϵRI β and γ chains, and the former was reactive with antibody to the FcϵRI β chain. Conversely, Western blots revealed the presence of p95 Vav in FcϵRI immunoprecipitates. The association of Vav and of Grb2 with the receptor was found to be regulated by aggregation of the receptor, and the interaction of Vav with the FcϵRI was localized to the γ chain. To gain insight on the signaling pathway in which Vav participates, we investigated the in vivo associations of Vav with other molecules. A reducible chemical cross-linking agent was used to covalently maintain protein interactions under nonreducing conditions. A fraction of Vav increased in mass to form a complex of >300 kDa in molecular mass. Under reducing conditions the cross-linked Vav immunoprecipitates showed the presence of Grb2, Raf-1, and p42mapk (ERK2). In vitro kinase assays of Raf-1 activity associated with Vav revealed that this complex had an activity greater than that of Raf-1 derived from nonactivated cells, and aggregation of the FcϵRI did not modulate this activity. In contrast, aggregation of the FcϵRI increased the total Raf-1 activity by 2-5-fold. These results demonstrate that Vav associates constitutively with components of the mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway to form an active multimeric signaling complex whose in vivo activity and associations may be directed by aggregation of the FcϵRI. The findings of this study may also be relevant to other members of the immune recognition receptor family that share the T-cell antigen receptor ζ/γ chains. Antigen triggering of mast cells and basophils via cell-bound immunoglobulin E (IgE) stimulates the activity of serine/threonine and tyrosine protein kinases leading to phosphorylation of multiple cellular substrates (1Benhamou M. Gutkind J.S. Robbins K.C. Siraganian R.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 5327-5330Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar, 2Li W. Deanin G.G. Margolis B. Schlessinger J. Oliver J.M. Mol. Cell Biol. 1992; 12: 3176-3182Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). A critical step in the antigen activation of mast cells is the phosphorylation of the high affinity receptor for IgE (FcϵRI) 1The abbreviations used are: FcϵRIthe high affinity receptor for IgEDNP-BSAdinitrophenyl25-bovine serum albuminDTSSP3,3′-dithiobis[sulfosuccinimidyl propionate]GEFguanine nucleotide exchange factorRas-GAPRas-GTPase activating proteinMAP kinasemitogen-activated protein kinaseERKextracellular-regulated protein kinaseCAPS3-[cyclohexylamino]-1-propanesulfonic acidITAMimmunoreceptor tyrosine-based activation motifGSTglutathione S-transferaseMEKMAP kinase/extracellular signal-regulated kinase. on both the β and γ chains of the tetrameric receptor (αβγγ) (3Quarto R. Metzger H. Mol. Immunol. 1986; 11: 1215-1223Crossref Scopus (30) Google Scholar, 4Paolini R. Jouvin M.-H. Kinet J.-P. Nature. 1991; 353: 855-858Crossref PubMed Scopus (222) Google Scholar). A number of molecules that participate either in the phosphorylation of the receptor or of other substrates, in response to aggregation of the receptor, have been identified. These include p56lyn (Lyn), pp60src (Src), p72syk (Syk), Bruton's tyrosine kinase, and PKC-δ (5Eiseman E. Bolen J.B. Nature. 1992; 355: 78-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (417) Google Scholar, 6Hutchcroft J.E. Geahlen R.L. Deanin G.G. Oliver J.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 9107-9111Crossref PubMed Scopus (207) Google Scholar, 7Kawakami Y. Yao L. Miura T. Tsukada S. Witte O.N. Kawakami T. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 5108-5113Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 8Germano P. Gomez J. Kazanietz M.G. Blumberg P.M. Rivera J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 23102-23107Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Evidence has been presented for the recruitment of some of these molecules to the receptor, in response to the phosphorylation of the immunoreceptor tyrosine-based activation motif (ITAM, 9) present on the β and γ chains of this receptor. Benhamou and colleagues (10Benhamou M. Ryba N.J.P. Kihara H. Nishikata H. Siraganian R.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 23318-23324Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) reported the association of the Syk with the γ chain as being dependent on the state of phosphorylation of the receptor. The src family kinase Lyn was found to associate with the FcϵRI (5Eiseman E. Bolen J.B. Nature. 1992; 355: 78-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (417) Google Scholar), and further recruitment of this kinase is dependent on aggregation of the receptor (11Yamashita T. Mao S.-Y. Metzger H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 11251-11255Crossref PubMed Scopus (160) Google Scholar). In general, these studies develop a theme analogous to growth factor receptors whereby phosphorylation of the receptor is critical for its ability to recruit molecules that link receptors to downstream effectors (12Margolis B. Rhee S.G. Felder S. Mervic M. Lyall R. Levitzki A. Ullrich A. Zilberstein A. Schlessinger J. Cell. 1989; 57: 1101-1107Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (513) Google Scholar). the high affinity receptor for IgE dinitrophenyl25-bovine serum albumin 3,3′-dithiobis[sulfosuccinimidyl propionate] guanine nucleotide exchange factor Ras-GTPase activating protein mitogen-activated protein kinase extracellular-regulated protein kinase 3-[cyclohexylamino]-1-propanesulfonic acid immunoreceptor tyrosine-based activation motif glutathione S-transferase MAP kinase/extracellular signal-regulated kinase. In the mast cell one potential downstream effector is Vav, a hematopoietic cell-specific protein that exhibits high homology to guanine nucleotide exchange factor (GEF) proteins (13Adams J.M. Houston H. Allen J. Lints T. Harvey R. Oncogene. 1992; 7: 611-618PubMed Google Scholar). Vav is expressed as a p95 proto-oncogene product or a p85 oncogenic product (14Bustelo X.R. Ledbetter J.A. Barbacid M. Nature. 1992; 356: 68-71Crossref PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar). The homology of the Vav with other members of the GEF family suggests that Vav may regulate guanine nucleotide exchange on the Rho family of GTP-binding proteins (13Adams J.M. Houston H. Allen J. Lints T. Harvey R. Oncogene. 1992; 7: 611-618PubMed Google Scholar). However, in T and B lymphocytes Vav was reported to exhibit an increased GDP exchange activity directed toward Ras (15Gulbins E. Coggeshall K.M. Baier G. Katzav S. Burn P. Altman A. Science. 1993; 260: 822-825Crossref PubMed Scopus (230) Google Scholar, 16Gulbins E. Langlet C. Baier G. Bonnefoy-Berard N. Herbert E. Altman A. Coggeshall K.M. J. Immunol. 1994; 152: 2123-2129PubMed Google Scholar). Subsequent studies suggest that Vav does not exhibit direct exchange activity toward Ras but requires Ras activity to demonstrate its phenotype (17Bustelo X.R. Suen K.-L. Leftheris K. Meyers C.A. Barbacid M. Oncogene. 1994; 9: 2405-2413PubMed Google Scholar). Whether Vav has intrinsic GEF activity toward Ras, or any other GTP-binding protein, or if its association with a GEF expressed in hematopoietic cells (18Clevenger C.V. Ngo W. Sokol D.L. Luger S.M. Gewirtz A.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 13246-13253Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar) accounts for the exhibited GEF activity is still unclear. Nevertheless, Vav has been shown to form a complex with a variety of proteins including ZAP 70, Grb2, and the RNA-binding protein, heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein K (19Katzav S. Sutherland M. Packham G. Yi T. Weiss A. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 32579-32585Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 20Ye Z.-S. Baltimore D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 12629-12633Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar, 21Hobert O. Jallal B. Schlessinger J. Ullrich A. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20225-20228Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). These associations may be important to its role in development of T and B cells as well as in T-cell antigen receptor signaling (22Zhang R. Alt F.W. Davidson L. Orkin S.H. Swat W. Nature. 1995; 374: 470-473Crossref PubMed Scopus (374) Google Scholar, 23Fischer K.-D. Zmuidzinas A. Gardner S. Barbacid M. Bernstein A. Guidos C. Nature. 1995; 374: 474-477Crossref PubMed Scopus (286) Google Scholar, 45Tarakhousky A. Turner M. Schaal S. Mee P.J. Duddy L.P. Rajewsky K. Tybulewicz V.L. Nature. 1995; 374: 467-470Crossref PubMed Scopus (390) Google Scholar). In contrast, other hematopoietic cells including cells of mast cell lineage appear to develop normally from progenitor cells that lack Vav (24Zmuidzinas A. Fischer K.-D. Lira S.A. Forrester L. Bryant S. Bernstein A. Barbacid M. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 1-11Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). Therefore it is possible that Vav might serve a different role in mast cells or, alternatively, other proteins might compensate for Vav signaling in these cells. Tyrosine phosphorylation of p95 Vav in response to aggregation of the FcϵRI (25Margolis B. Hu P. Katzav S. Li W. Oliver J.M. Ullrich A. Weiss A. Schlessinger J. Nature. 1992; 356: 71-74Crossref PubMed Scopus (307) Google Scholar) suggests a role for this protein in receptor-mediated signal transduction in mast cells. The phosphorylation of Vav has been linked to the expression of Syk kinase activity in the mucosal mast cell model, RBL-2H3 (26Hirasawa N. Scharenberg A. Yamamura H. Beaven M.A. Kinet J.-P. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 10960-10967Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (140) Google Scholar). Since Syk is recruited to the FcϵRI upon its aggregation (10Benhamou M. Ryba N.J.P. Kihara H. Nishikata H. Siraganian R.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 23318-23324Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), we have investigated whether a potential downstream effector such as Vav could associate with the receptor and might this association be regulated by aggregation of the receptor. Furthermore, to gain insights as to the signaling pathway in which Vav participates in mast cells, we analyzed which proteins complex with Vav in vivo and determined if kinase activity is associated with Vav. Anti-dinitrophenyl (DNP)-specific mouse monoclonal IgE (27Liu F.-T. Bohn J.W. Ferry E.L. Yamamoto H. Molinaro C.A. Sherman L.A. Klinman N.R. Katz D.H. J. Immunol. 1980; 124: 2728-2737PubMed Google Scholar) was purified as described previously (28Holowka D. Metzger H. Mol. Immunol. 1982; 19: 219-227Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). Goat anti-mouse IgE was purchased from ICN (Costa Mesa, CA). The monoclonal antibody to the FcϵRI β chain (mAbβ JRK) was purified as described (29Rivera J. Kinet J.-P. Kim J. Pucillo C. Metzger H. Mol. Immunol. 1988; 25: 647-661Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). Rabbit polyclonal or mouse monoclonal antibodies reactive to ERK1 or ERK2, Grb2, MEK1, Pan Ras, PLCγ, Shc, Sos 1/2, Rac1/2, Raf-1/2, Ras-GAP, p56lyn, ZAP 70, RhoA, RhoB, Rho-GAP were purchased from either Santa Cruz Biotech, Santa Cruz, CA, Transduction Laboratories, Lexington, KY, or Upstate Biotechnologies, Lake Placid, NY. Rabbit polyclonal antibodies to Vav, raised to either a peptide corresponding to amino acids 528-541 of human Vav or to a 20.6-kDa fragment of human Vav (amino acids 620-797), were purchased from Santa Cruz Biotech or Transduction Laboratories, respectively. A mouse monoclonal antibody to Vav raised to a glutathione S-transferase-fusion protein of full-length human Vav was purchased from Upstate Biotech. Rabbit antisera to Syk was kindly provided by Dr. R. Siraganian (NIDR, NIH). Purified normal rabbit or goat IgG was purchased from Jackson Immunoresearch, West Grove, PA. The 2H3 subline of RBL cells was cultured as a monolayer in stationary flasks essentially as described (30Barsumian E.L. Isersky C. Petrino M.G. Siraganian R.P. Eur. J. Immunol. 1981; 11: 317-322Crossref PubMed Scopus (485) Google Scholar). For experiments the cells were sensitized with 125I-labeled or unlabeled dinitrophenyl-specific mouse monoclonal IgE (as indicated) at 2.5 μg/ml for 5 × 106 cells/ml for 1 h at room temperature or by addition directly to the culture flask of 1 μg/ml overnight at 37°C. Cells in modified Tyrode's buffer (31Furuichi K. Rivera J. Isersky C. J. Immunol. 1984; 133: 1513-1520PubMed Google Scholar) were activated by incubation with 0.4-1.0 μg/ml dinitrophenylated bovine serum albumin (DNP-BSA) at 37°C for 3 min or for the indicated time. Activation was stopped by the immediate addition of a 2 × ice-cold lysis buffer (see below). For some experiments cells in media were activated as above, and activation was quenched by addition of ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline, pH 7.4, cells were washed in ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline and lysed. For studies to analyze the association of Vav with receptor, 0.5-5.0 × 107 cells previously labeled with 125I-IgE were solubilized at a final concentration of 0.0625% Triton X-100 (Research Products International, Mount Prospect, IL) for 5 × 106 cells. All solutions contained protease and phosphatase inhibitors as described (32Pribluda V.S. Metzger H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 11446-11450Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). Solubilization was for 1 h at 4°C which allowed for recovery of greater than 95% of the nonaggregated and DNP-BSA-aggregated receptor. Soluble cell lysates were recovered after a 15-min microcentrifugation at 13,000 × g. Lysates were treated with protein G or protein A-Sepharose for 1 h at 4°C. The cleared lysates were subsequently incubated with goat anti-mouse IgE (10-20 μl) or with 10 μg of rabbit antibodies to Vav, Lyn, Grb2, ZAP 70, and rabbit IgG for each individual sample. Protein G or protein A-Sepharose was added after 2 h, and incubation was continued overnight at 4°C. Recovered immunoprecipitates were washed 6 × in 0.01% Triton X-100 containing protease and phosphatase inhibitors. 125I-IgE receptors recovered in the immunoprecipitates of Vav, Lyn, Grb2, and ZAP 70 were quantitated by counting in a Packard Minaxi Auto Gamma 5000 (Downers Grove, IL). Samples of the immunoprecipitated proteins were also solubilized in Tris glycine-SDS sample buffer and proteins resolved by SDS-PAGE. For analysis of Vav-associated proteins, cells (2 × 107) were solubilized in 0.5% Triton X-100 containing protease and phosphatase inhibitors and Vav, ERKs or Syk were immunoprecipitated by addition of 10 μg of anti-Vav or anti-ERK or 40 μg of an IgG fraction of anti-Syk followed by protein A-Sepharose. The immunoprecipitates were washed 5 times in 0.5% Triton X-100 and 1 time in 0.01% Triton X-100 and solubilized in Tris glycine-SDS sample buffer. Proteins were resolved and immunoblotted as described below. For chemical cross-linking experiments nonactivated or activated cells (2 × 107) were solubilized in cross-linking buffer (25 mM HEPES, pH 8.0, 5 mM KCl, 119.4 mM NaCl, 5.6 mM glucose, 1 mM MgCl2, and 0.5 mM CaCl2) containing 1% Nonidet P-40 (Nonidet P-40) with protease and phosphatase inhibitors. The soluble cell lysates were incubated, for 30 min on ice, with 2 mM DTSSP (3,3′-dithiobis[sulfosuccinimidyl propionate]), pH 8.0, a concentration determined to cause effective cross-linking and maintain antibody reactivity. Reaction was stopped by addition of 40 mM glycine and further incubation on ice for 20 min. Immunoprecipitation was as described above, and recovered pellets were vigorously washed 5 times in RIPA buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, 1% Nonidet P-40, 150 mM NaCl, 0.5% sodium deoxycholate, 0.1% SDS) followed by 1 time in 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.4. The antibodies used to detect cross-linked proteins were tested for their ability to recognize the protein in chemically cross-linked cell lysates. This association was specific since associations with GST or with other GST-fusion proteins were not observed, and probing of the GST-fusion proteins with antibody to PKC-δ revealed this isozyme was associated with the GST-βc construct as described previously (data not shown, 8). An increased association of Vav with GST-γ could not be detected with Vav derived from either nonactivated or activated cells. Interestingly, only the 95-kDa protein reactive with both polyclonal and monoclonal antibodies to Vav was observed with the GST-γ-fusion protein or with receptor, although a Vav antibody-reactive protein of 85 kDa (which appears to be a proteolytic product of Vav; data not shown) is detected in cell lysates. The association of the FcϵRI with Vav or Grb2 is regulated by aggregation of the receptor (Fig. 4). In close agreement with the data presented in the previous section, relative quantitation of immunoblots showed that approximately 2% of the receptors were co-immunoprecipitated with both Vav and Grb2 (Fig. 4A) after aggregation of the receptor. While these results suggest that receptors interact with Vav or Grb2, only after aggregation of the receptors, long exposures of the immunoblots revealed the presence of the β chain in the immunoprecipitates derived from nonaggregated cells (data not shown). This is consistent with the data shown in Fig. 3A. Nevertheless, an enhancement of the association is seen upon aggregation of the receptor, and kinetic analysis of receptor association with Vav revealed that peak association occurs between 1 and 3 min, a time when the phosphorylation of the receptor is maximal (Fig. 4B and Fig. 2). Collectively, the data suggest that a 2-4-fold enhancement of Vav in association with the receptor is mediated by the aggregation of the FcϵRI. Disregulation of vitamin A metabolism is able to generate different immunological effects, including altered response to infection, reduced IgG production, and differential regulation of cytokine gene expression (including interleukin-2 and −4 and interferon-γ (IFN-γ)). In particular, IFN-γ gene expression is significantly affected by vitamin A and/or its derivatives (e.g. retinoic acid (RA)). Here, we analyze the effect of retinoic acid on IFN-γ transcription. Transient transfection assays in the human T lymphoblastoid cell line Jurkat demonstrated that the activation of the IFN-γ promoter was significantly down-regulated in the presence of RA. Surprisingly, two different AP-1/CREB-ATF-binding elements situated in the initial 108 base pairs of the IFN-γ promoter and previously shown to be critical for transcriptional activity were unaffected by RA. Utilizing promoter deletions and electrophoretic mobility shift analysis, we identified a USF/EGR-1-binding element cooperating in the modulation of IFN-γ promoter activity by RA. This element was found to be situated in a position of the IFN-γ promoter close to a silencer element previously identified in our laboratory. These results suggest that direct modulation of IFN-γ promoter activity is one of the possible mechanisms involved in the inhibitory effect of retinoids on IFN-γ gene expression. Utilizing promoter deletions and electrophoretic mobility shift analysis, we identified a USF/EGR-1-binding element cooperating in the modulation of IFN-γ promoter activity by RA. This element was found to be situated in a position of the IFN-γ promoter close to a silencer element previously identified in our laboratory. These results suggest that direct modulation of IFN-γ promoter activity is one of the possible mechanisms involved in the inhibitory effect of retinoids on IFN-γ gene expression.

The N-terminal region of skeletal myosin light chain-1 (MLC-1) binds to the C terminus of actin, yet the functional significance of this interaction is unclear. We studied a fragment (MLC-pep; residues 5-14) of the ventricular MLC-1. When added to rat cardiac myofibrils, 10 nM MLC-pep induced a supramaximal increase in the MgATPase activity at submaximal Ca2+ levels with no effect at low and maximal Ca2+ levels. A nonsense, scrambled sequence peptide had no effect at any pCa value. MLC-pep did not affect myosin KEDTA and CaATPase activities or actin-activated MgATPase activities in the absence or presence of tropomyosin. The MLC-pep did not alter the ability of troponin I to inhibit MgATPase activity. Moreover, when troponin I and troponin C were extracted from the myofibrils, the MLC-pep lost its ability to stimulate the ATPase rate. This effect was fully restored upon reconstitution of the extracted myofibrils with troponin I-troponin C complex. Thus, activation of MgATPase activity by the peptide required a full complement of thin filament regulatory proteins. Interestingly, the stimulatory effect occurred at a ratio of 4 peptides to 1 thin filament, suggesting that the peptide engages in a highly cooperative process that may involve activation of the entire thin filament. Erythropoietin regulates the transcription of the protooncogenes c-myc and c-myb by discrete protein kinase C (PKC)-dependent and protein serine/threonine phosphatase-dependent pathways, respectively (Spangler, R., Bailey, S. C., and Sytkowski, A. J. (1991) J. Biol. Chem. 266, 681-684; Patel H. R, Choi H.-S, and Sytkowski A. J. (1992) J. Biol. Chem. 267, 21300-21302). In the present study we demonstrate that up-regulation of c-myc requires the PKC-ε isoform and that this pathway is required for erythropoietin-induced DNA synthesis (growth) but apparently not for β-globin expression (differentiation). Treatment of Rauscher murine erythroleukemia cells resulted in phosphorylation of phospholipase C-γ1 and activation of PKC-ε as evidenced by its translocation from soluble to particulate subcellular fractions. Artificial down-regulation of PKC-ε with antisense oligodeoxynucleotides blocked erythropoietin's up-regulation of c-myc in a concentration-dependent manner. In contrast, antisense oligodeoxynucleotides to PKC-α, -β, -γ, -δ, and -ζ had no effect. Although down-regulation of PKC-ε blocked the increase in c-myc expression, it did not inhibit erythropoietin induction of β-globin expression, a marker of erythroid differentiation. However, down-regulation of PKC-ε did block factor-dependent DNA synthesis quantified by measurement of [3H]thymidine incorporation into newly synthesized DNA of normal murine erythroid cells. The results are consistent with discrete intracellular signals regulating erythroid cell growth and differentiation. Bailey S.C. Sytkowski A.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 681-684Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 11Spangler R. Sytkowski A.J. After exposure to x-ray film, the relative intensities of c-myc and GAPDH transcripts in each lane were determined by quantitative scanning laser densitometer (LKB, Uppsala, Sweden). Cells grown in culture were collected by centrifugation at 2000 × g for 5 min, washed in cold hypotonic buffer, containing 5 mM KCl, 0.5 mM MgCl2, 0.5 mM dithiothreitol, 20 mM HEPES, and 200 mM sucrose, pH 7.5 (25Challberg M.D. Kelly Jr T.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1979; 76: 655-659Crossref PubMed Scopus (145) Google Scholar), and resuspended in hypotonic buffer without sucrose. After incubation on ice for 10 min, cells were lysed by 25 strokes of a tight fitting Dounce homogenizer (ball A). The cell lysates were centrifuged at 2000 × g for 5 min at 4°C. The supernatant was then mixed with an equal volume of 2 × SDS sample buffer (0.375 M Tris-HCI, 4% SDS, 20% glycerol, 3.1% dithiothreitol, pH 6.8) and heated in boiling water for 5 min. Samples were centrifuged at 37,000 × g for 90 min, subjected to 7% SDS-PAGE, and transferred electrophoretically to a polyvinylidene difluoride membrane (Hoefer Scientific Instruments). The membrane was blocked in PBST buffer (137 mM NaCl, 2 mM KCl, 5 mM Na2HPO4, 1.7 mM KH2PO4, 0.1% Tween-20, pH 7.4) containing 10% non-fat dry milk (w/v) at room temperature for 4 h followed by an incubation in PBST containing affinity-purified anti-PKC-ε antibody (0.5 μg/ml) (Life Technologies, Inc.) and 5% non-fat dry milk for 12 h at 4°C. After three 15-min washes in PBST, the membrane was incubated in horseradish peroxidase-conjugated goat anti-rabbit IgG (Vector Laboratories) (1:1000 dilution in PBST, 5% non-fat dry milk) for 1 h at room temperature. Proteins were detected using ECL Western blotting kit (Amersham Corp.). PCR primers for PKC-ε and PKC-ζ were derived from the published sequences of respective PKC isoform cDNA. The sequences of the primers and their positions in the coding sequences are as follows: PKC-ε, 5′ primer, 5′-ACGTTCTGTGACCACTGT (944-961); 3′ primer, 5′-CTTGCCAAAGCTGCCTTT (1431-1448); PKC-ζ, 5′ primer, 5′-GCGTACTGTGGCCAGTGC (572-589); 3′ primer, 5′-CTTGGCATAGCTTCCACG (925-942). First strand cDNA was synthesized by incubating 1 μg of cellular RNA in 20 μl of reverse transcription reaction containing 250 mM Tris-HCl, 375 mM KCl 15 mM MgCl2, 1 uM oligo(dT)18, 1 mM each of dATP, dCTP, dGTP, and dTTP, 200 units of Moloney murine leukemia virus reverse transcriptase (Clontech Laboratories, Inc.), pH 8.3, at 42°C for 1 h. One-tenth of the reaction was used for PCR amplification. PCR amplification was carried out in standard buffer (Perkin-Elmer) with 2 mM MgCl2 for 35 cycles of 95°C/1 min, 50°C (55°C for PKC-ζ)/30 s, and 72°C/2 min in a Perkin-Elmer DNA thermal cycler 480. For internal controls, human GAPDH primers (1 μM) (Clontech Laboratories, Inc.) flanking a 1-kilobase pair GAPDH cDNA fragment were included in each PCR reaction. The PCR products were resolved in a 1.2% agarose gel and visualized with ethidium bromide staining. The ability of antisense oligodeoxynucleotides to block erythropoietin's mitotic signal was examined in the standard in vitro bioassay that measures erythropoietin-stimulated incorporation of [3H]thymidine into newly synthesized DNA of normal murine splenic erythroid cells (17Krystal G. Exp. Hematol. 1983; 11: 649-660PubMed Google Scholar). For each assay, a standard curve of 5-200 milliunits of erythropoietin/ml was used. Each oligo was added in the presence of 50 milliunits of erythropoietin/ml, a value chosen for its position in the linear portion of the standard curve. Samples were assayed in triplicate, and variation among replicates was ±5%. For these studies thymidine-free oligos were used (see sequences above) in order to avoid reducing the specific activity of the [3H]thymidine intracellularly, which can result in a spurious decrease in measured [3H]thymidine incorporation (26Heikkila R. Schwab G. Wickstrom E. Loke S.L. Pluznik D.H. Watt R. Neckers L.M. Nature. 1987; 328: 445-449Crossref PubMed Scopus (545) Google Scholar). Our previous studies using molecular blocking agents demonstrated that erythropoietin's signal to c-myc is dependent upon PKC (10Spangler R. Bailey S.C. Sytkowski A.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 681-684Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 11Spangler R. Sytkowski A.J. Blood. 1992; 79: 52-57Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In order to begin to identify the specific PKC isoform(s) involved, we carried out preliminary loss-of-function experiments using antisense oligodeoxynucleotides. Rauscher murine erythroleukemia cells were incubated for 18 h in the absence or presence of antisense oligodeoxynucleotides to PKC-α, -β, -γ, -δ, -ε, or -ζ, 100 μg/ml, followed by 100 units of erythropoietin/ml for 1 h. We have shown previously that this time of exposure to erythropoietin is optimal for demonstrating the up-regulation of c-myc expression (9Chern Y.E. Spangler R. Choi H.-S Sytkowski A.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 2009-2012Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 10Spangler R. Bailey S.C. Sytkowski A.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 681-684Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The cells were lysed, RNA was prepared, and Northern analyses were carried out to quantify c-myc and GAPDH (control) steady-state mRNA levels. In the absence of antisense oligos, erythropoietin up-regulated c-myc expression 3-4-fold. Of the six antisense oligos tested, only antisense PKC-ε achieved significant inhibition (60%) of erythropoietin's c-myc up-regulation. Based upon these initial screening experiments, we selected PKC-ε for further study. We demonstrated that erythropoietin treatment of Rauscher cells results in activation of PKC-ε by quantifying the amount of PKC-ε in the soluble and particulate cellular fractions of cells incubated in the absence or presence of the hormone. Cells were incubated for 5 min in the absence or presence of erythropoietin. The soluble and particulate fractions were subjected to SDS-PAGE and Western blotting with anti-PKC-ε antibody. As seen in Fig. 1, cells incubated in the absence of erythropoietin exhibited 77% of PKC-ε in the soluble fraction and 23% in the particulate fraction. In contrast, erythropoietin treatment induced a marked translocation of PKC-ε, resulting in only 8% in the soluble fraction and 92% in the particulate fraction. The results of repeated experiments were very similar. Consistent with the activation (translocation) of PKC-ε shown above is the demonstration that erythropoietin induces tyrosine phosphorylation of phospholipase C-γ1 in Rauscher cells. We treated the cells for 5 min, prepared lysates, and subjected them to immunoprecipitation with mixed monoclonal antibodies to PLC-γ1. The immunoprecipitates were subjected to SDS-PAGE and Western blotting with anti-phosphotyrosine and anti-PLC-γ1 antibodies (Fig. 2). In the absence of erythropoietin, no tyrosine-phosphorylated protein was detected in the range of 145 kDa. However, after erythropoietin treatment, a distinct 145-kDa band was detected with anti-phosphotyrosine. Importantly, this band coincided precisely with the 145-kDa PLC-γ1 band visualized using anti-PLC-γ1 antibody. As expected, the total amounts of PLC-γ1 protein detected in untreated and treated cells were identical. These results are in agreement with previous work demonstrating the induction of PLC-γ1 tyrosine phosphorylation after erythropoietin treatment of a different cell line (27Ren H-Y Komatsu N. Shimizu R. Okada K. Miura Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 19633-19638Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Antisense PKC-ε oligos blocked the erythropoietin-dependent up-regulation of c-myc in a concentration-dependent manner. As seen in Fig. 3, erythropoietin up-regulated c-myc expression 2.5-fold. Treatment with 0, 50, 100, 150, or 200 μg of antisense PKC-ε oligo/ml inhibited erythropoietin's induction of c-myc in a concentration-dependent manner, reducing the level of c-myc expression down to that seen in the absence of erythropoietin, but not below. As a control experiment, missense oligos with the same nucleotide composition were used. No effect on erythropoietin's up-regulation of c-myc was observed (Fig. 4).Fig. 4Lack of effect of missense PKC-ε oligodeoxynucleotide on erythropoietin's up-regulation of c-myc expression. The experiment was performed as in the legend to Fig. 3.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) We confirmed that antisense PKC-ε oligo treatment had down-regulated PKC-ε transcript by reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR) (Fig. 5). Total cellular RNA from cells incubated in the absence or presence of antisense or missense oligos was reverse transcribed, and the cDNA was PCR amplified using primers specific for PKC-ε as well as primers specific for GAPDH, a control transcript. The PKC-ε primers amplified a single 505-bp product, the exact size predicted from the primers selected. Importantly, this product was not detected using RNA from cells treated with antisense PKC-ε oligo, but was detected using RNA from cells treated with the missense oligo. A 1000-bp GAPDH product was co-amplified equally using RNA from cells incubated under each of the three conditions, confirming the specificity of the antisense PKC-ε effect. We also confirmed the action of antisense PKC-ε oligo by demonstrating down-regulation of PKC-ε protein using Western blot analysis of cell lysates (Fig. 6). PKC-ε was readily detected as a ∼94-95-kDa protein. Its abundance was not changed by erythropoietin treatment, as expected. This is consistent with our previous observation that erythropoietin up-regulates c-myc as a primary response gene (cycloheximide resistant) (9Chern Y.E. Spangler R. Choi H.-S Sytkowski A.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 2009-2012Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Importantly, PKC-ε protein was reduced by 77% (to 23% of control) in cells treated with antisense PKC-ε oligo. As a further control for the specificity of the antisense PKC-ε effect, we carried out similarly detailed experiments using antisense oligos to another isoform expressed in these cells, PKC-ζ. In contrast to the marked effect of PKC-ε down-regulation on erythropoietin's signal to c-myc, antisense oligos to PKC-ζ had no effect (Fig. 7). Cells were treated with antisense PKC-ζ oligos at the same concentrations as those used for PKC-ε. No inhibition of erythropoietin-induced c-myc expression was observed for all of the concentrations of antisense PKC-ζ oligo tested. We confirmed that antisense PKC-ζ oligos did indeed down-regulate PKC-ζ in these experiments by RT-PCR (Fig. 8). RT-PCR with primers specific for PKC-ζ resulted in amplification of the expected 371-bp product using RNA from untreated cells. This PKC-ζ product was no longer detected when RNA from cells treated with antisense PKC-ζ oligo was used. The control 1000-bp GAPDH product was co-amplified equally using RNA from either cell preparation. As noted above, antisense oligos to four other isoforms (α, β, γ, and δ) also did not affect the c-myc response. We did not perform similarly extensive experiments documenting the effect of these oligos on their respective target transcripts and proteins.Fig. 8Effect of antisense (A.S.) PKC-ζ oligodeoxynucleotides on PKC-ζ mRNA in Rauscher cells. Note absence of the 371-bp product in A.S.+ cells. See Fig. 5.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) Previous studies of c-myc in Friend murine erythroleukemia cells, which differentiate when treated with various chemical agents but not with erythropoietin, have demonstrated that changes in the c-myc expression are necessary for this differentiation (28Lachman M.M. Skoultchi A.I. Nature. 1984; 310: 592-594Crossref PubMed Scopus (255) Google Scholar, 29Coppola J.A. Cole M.D. Nature. 1986; 320: 760-763Crossref PubMed Scopus (328) Google Scholar, 30Dmitrovsky E. Kuehl W.M. Hollis G.F. Kirsch I.R. Bender T.P. Segal S. Nature. 1986; 322: 748-750Crossref PubMed Scopus (199) Google Scholar, 31Prochownik E.V. Kukowska J. Nature. 1986; 322: 848-850Crossref PubMed Scopus (203) Google Scholar). Therefore, we investigated whether blocking erythropoietin's signal to c-myc with antisense oligos to PKC-ε would prevent differentiation of Rauscher cells induced by the growth factor. Cells were incubated in the absence or presence of specified concentrations of antisense PKC-ε oligo for 24 h followed by another 24 h of incubation with erythropoietin to induce differentiation. These are conditions under which PKC-ε mRNA is completely down-regulated. Total cellular RNA was prepared and subjected to Northern analysis using a probe for β-globin (Fig. 9). Erythropoietin's induction of β-globin mRNA was equivalent (3-4-fold) whether or not its signal to c-myc had been blocked. This indicates that the up-regulation of c-myc is not necessary for erythropoietin-induced differentiation and either that PKC-ε is also not necessary or that it is required at a much lower concentration. In marked contrast, we found that PKC-ε is clearly necessary for erythropoietin-induced cell growth. To demonstrate this we measured the erythropoietin-dependent incorporation of [3H]thymidine into newly synthesized DNA of normal murine splenic erythroid cells. This assay is acknowledged widely as a standard in vitro bioassay for erythropoietin. Addition of increasing concentrations of antisense PKC-ε oligo to cells treated with a constant amount of erythropoietin resulted in a concentration-dependent inhibition of DNA synthesis down to 28% of that seen in the absence of oligo (72% inhibition) (Fig. 10, closed circles). Interestingly, the percent of growth inhibition was nearly identical to the percent reduction in PKC-ε protein achieved with antisense oligos (Fig. 6). No growth inhibition was seen when the missense oligo was used (Fig. 10, open circles). In the present study we have begun to elucidate the PKC-dependent signal transduction pathway by which the hematopoietic growth factor erythropoietin regulates expression of the proto-oncogene, c-myc. We have now correlated the activation of this pathway with erythropoietin's mitogenic signal. In previous work we demonstrated that the proto-oncogenes c-myc and c-myb are both regulated by erythropoietin as primary response genes (immediate/early genes); that is, their regulation does not require de novo protein synthesis (9Chern Y.E. Spangler R. Choi H.-S Sytkowski A.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 2009-2012Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We used c-myc and c-myb as endogenous reporter genes to monitor the arrival of erythropoietin's signal in the nucleus (10Spangler R. Bailey S.C. Sytkowski A.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 681-684Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 11Spangler R. Sytkowski A.J. Blood. 1992; 79: 52-57Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 12Patel H.R Choi H.-S Sytkowski A.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 21300-21302Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Using molecular blocking agents we showed that each gene is regulated transcriptionally (by modulation of transcriptional attenuation) via discrete signaling pathways. Erythropoietin's up-regulation of c-myc requires a PKC-dependent pathway, whereas its down-regulation of c-myb is dependent upon a class 1,2a protein phosphatase. We have now shown that erythropoietin's PKC-dependent signal to c-myc requires PKC-ε, a member of the calcium-independent group of PKC isoforms. Moreover, artificial down-regulation of PKC-ε blocks erythropoietin's mitogenic signal, but has no apparent effect on the hormone's ability to induce differentiation, i.e. globin expression. PKC-ε is clearly required for erythropoietin-induced up-regulation of c-myc and for DNA synthesis. There are at least two potential modes by which PKC-ε may function. Firstly, it may directly mediate the signal pathway to c-myc and DNA synthesis, i.e. serve a causal role. Secondly, it may be necessary for other reactions and processes that are required for efficient transmission of the effector signal, i.e. a “permissive” role. The present data do not allow an unequivocal decision to be made regarding which of these alternatives is the more likely. Whether or not the signal pathway to c-myc is identical to that which mediates erythropoietin's “anti-apoptotic” effect (32Koury M.J. Bondurant M.C. Science. 1990; 248: 378-381Crossref PubMed Scopus (722) Google Scholar) has not yet been determined. In these studies we employed two different cell types. Rauscher murine erythroleukemia cells do not require erythropoietin for proliferation. Therefore, they proved especially useful in assessing potentially differentiation-specific processes. Normal murine erythroid cells were used to assess potentially growth-specific processes. Although our previous studies have indicated excellent agreement between these two cell systems with respect to signaling events (11Spangler R. Sytkowski A.J. Blood. 1992; 79: 52-57Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), it is, nonetheless, possible that differences exist between their erythropoietin induced signal pathways. For example, although Rauscher cells may not require PKC-ε for globin expression, the same conclusion cannot yet be made for normal cells. Unfortunately, their factordependent and PKC-ε-dependent growth requirement in all likelihood precludes designing a definitive experiment to answer this question. With acknowledgement of these several alternatives, we propose the hypothesis that erythropoietin may trigger separate growth and differentiation signals (or groups of signals) which may be subject to differential manipulation. There is other evidence in support of such a “two-signal” hypothesis. Erythroid progenitor cells infected with Friend erythroleukemia virus and related viruses become independent of erythropoietin for their proliferation (33D'Andrea A. Li J. Baltimore D. Lodish H.F. Nature. 1990; 343: 762-764Crossref PubMed Scopus (348) Google Scholar). This is apparently due to activation of their endogenous erythropoietin receptor (EpoR) by its interaction with the virally encoded gp55. However, this EpoR-gp55 interaction does not trigger differentiation, suggesting “uncoupling” of the EpoR growth and differentiation signals. Recently, transforming growth factor-β has been shown to induce differentiation of normal human erythroid cells while decreasing their growth (34Krystal G. Lam V. Dragowski W. Takahashi C. Appel J. Gontier A. Jenkins A. Lam H. Quon L. Lansdorp P. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 180: 851-860Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar). It is unclear whether the two hypothetical signals could be mapped topographically to discrete domains of the erythropoietin receptor. Several direct (protein-protein) interactions have been documented between the receptor and signal transduction effector molecules (1Damen J.E. Mui A.L. Puil L. Pawson T. Krystal G. Blood. 1993; 81: 3204-3210Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 2Mayeux P. Dusanter-Fourt I. Muller O. Mauduit P. Sabbah M. Druker B. Vainchenker W. Fischer S. Lacombe C. Gisselbrecht S. Eur. J. Biochem. 1993; 216: 821-828Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar, 3Miura O. Nakumura N. Ihle J.N. Aoki N. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 614-620Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 4Witthuhn B.A. Quelle F.W. Silvennoinen O. Yi T. Tang B. Miura O. Ihle J.N. Cell. 1993; 74: 227-236Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1008) Google Scholar). It is possible that the proliferative signal might result from one such interaction while the differentiation signal might result from another. Moreover, it is not known whether each individual receptor molecule (or receptor-receptor dimer) is capable of generating both (all) signals, i.e. interacts simultaneously with all signal transduction molecules. Also, the proliferative and differentiation limbs may result from a single interaction that results in a signal which bifurcates downstream. Other studies have implicated PKC in erythroid cell differentiation and growth. Melloni et al. (35Melloni E. Pntremoli S. Sparatore B. Patrone M. Grossi F. Marks P.A. Rifkind R.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci U. S. A. 1990; 87: 4417-4420Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar) reported originally that the incorporation of partially purified PKC-β into Friend murine erythroleukemia cells accelerated chemically induced differentiation. These investigators later revised their identification of the isoform in question to PKC-ε (36Powell C.T. Leng L. Dong L. Kiyokawa H. Busquets X. O'Driscoll K. Marks P.A. Rifkind R.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci U. S. A. 1992; 89: 147-151Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). Most recently it has been suggested that PKC-α, -δ, -ε, -ζ, and -η may all play a role in this enhancement of chemically induced Friend cell differentiation (37Leng L. Yu F. Dong L. Busquets X. Osada S. Richon V.M. Marks P.A. Rifkind R.A. Cancer Res. 1993; 53: 5554-5558PubMed Google Scholar). A PKC-like activity localized to the nucleus of Friend cells has been reported as necessary for cell proliferation (38Beckman B.S. Exp. Hematol. 1992; 20: 324-327PubMed Google Scholar). Its abundance is apparently decreased by chemical inducers. However, such chemical agents induce differentiation of these cells by a mechanism that is different from erythropoietin signaling, that is, the receptor is by-passed. Thus, it is likely that the role of PKC isoforms in enhancing chemically induced differentiation also differs from that played by PKC-ε in erythropoietin signaling. The PKC-ε isoform has been associated with numerous functions in a wide variety of cell types. Perhaps of special relevance to the data presented here are observations indicating that its overexpression in fibroblasts is transforming, indicating that it can function as an oncogene (39Mischak H. Goodnight J. Kolch W. Martiny-Baron G. Schaechtle C. Kazanietz M.G. Blumberg P.M. Pierce J.H. Mushinski J.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 6090-6096Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), consistent with its role in erythropoietin's mitogenic action. PKC-ε may not be the only isoform capable of transducing erythropoietin's mitogenic (anti-apoptotic?) signal under all circumstances. 5 et al. (40May W.S. Tyler P.G. Ito T. Armstrong D.K. Qatsha K.A. Davidson N.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 26865-26870Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) have reported that the suppression of apoptosis in FDC-P1/ER cells associated with expression of bcl2 protein is mediated by PKC-α. This would imply that the functions of the various PKC isoforms are quite lineage-specific, even among the various types of hematopoietic cells. However, evidence indicates that the “mitogenic” and “anti-apoptotic” actions of erythropoietin and, presumably, other growth factors are not identical (41Spivak J.L. Pham T. Isaacs M. Hankins W.D. Blood. 1991; 77: 1228-1233Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), suggesting that the erythropoietin's growth enhancing signaling mechanism consists of more than one pathway. Erythropoietin has been reported to induce nuclear localization of PKC-β isoforms (42). It would be of interest to compare the levels of expression of PKC isoforms in various erythroid cells, both normal and transformed, from several species. It is unknown at present whether the role of PKC-ε in erythropoietin's mitogenic signal demonstrated in the present study can be performed by other isoforms in other erythroid cells. Further identification of the kinases and their substrates involved in these processes will help to clarify these questions. We thank Mrs. Rosemary Panza for her editorial expertise and Elanex Pharmaceuticals for their gift of recombinant erythropoietin.

The members of the myristoylated alanine-rich Ckinase substrate (MARCKS) family are proteins essential for brain development and phagocytosis. MARCKS proteins bind to actin filaments and calmodulin (CaM) and are phosphorylated by protein kinase C. In order to investigate how these interactions are regulated, we have characterized the properties of both the myristoylated (myr) and unmyristoylated (unmyr) forms of recombinant MARCKS-related protein (MRP), a 20-kDa member of the MARCKS family.Ultracentrifugation and circular dichroic spectroscopy reveal that MRP is an elongated protein, with an axis ratio estimated between 7 and 12 and with an apparent random coil conformation. MRP binds to CaM with high affinity (Kd,myr = 4 nM; Kd,unmyr = 7 nM) and with a second order rate constant, k+1,unmyr, of 1.6 × 108M−1 s−1. In contrast to classical ligands such as the myosin light chain kinase, binding of MRP to CaM does not induce the formation of an α-helix in MRP. The catalytic subunit of protein kinase C (PKM) phosphorylates myr MRP with high affinity ([S]0.5 = 3.5 μM), positive cooperativity (nH = 2.5) and a turnover number of 130 min−1. CaM inhibits the phosphorylation of myr MRP with a half-maximum rate of phosphorylation at a [CaM]/[MRP] ratio of 0.7, indicating that CaM might efficiently regulate the phosphorylation of MRP in vivo. Interestingly, Ca2+ inhibits the binding of MRP to CaM as well as its phosphorylation by PKM in the millimolar concentration range, suggesting that MRP has a weak affinity for Ca2+.Finally, unmyr MRP can be stoichiometrically myristoylated by N-myristoyl transferase in vitro. Since neither binding of CaM nor phosphorylation by PKM inhibits myristoylation, the N terminus of unmyr MRP is exposed on the surface of the protein and is well separated from the effector domain. In view of the observations that unmyr and myr MRP do not exhibit significant differences in their properties in solution, the function of myristoylation is most probably to modulate the interactions of MRP with membranes. The members of the myristoylated alanine-rich Ckinase substrate (MARCKS) family are proteins essential for brain development and phagocytosis. MARCKS proteins bind to actin filaments and calmodulin (CaM) and are phosphorylated by protein kinase C. In order to investigate how these interactions are regulated, we have characterized the properties of both the myristoylated (myr) and unmyristoylated (unmyr) forms of recombinant MARCKS-related protein (MRP), a 20-kDa member of the MARCKS family. Ultracentrifugation and circular dichroic spectroscopy reveal that MRP is an elongated protein, with an axis ratio estimated between 7 and 12 and with an apparent random coil conformation. MRP binds to CaM with high affinity (Kd,myr = 4 nM; Kd,unmyr = 7 nM) and with a second order rate constant, k+1,unmyr, of 1.6 × 108M−1 s−1. In contrast to classical ligands such as the myosin light chain kinase, binding of MRP to CaM does not induce the formation of an α-helix in MRP. The catalytic subunit of protein kinase C (PKM) phosphorylates myr MRP with high affinity ([S]0.5 = 3.5 μM), positive cooperativity (nH = 2.5) and a turnover number of 130 min−1. CaM inhibits the phosphorylation of myr MRP with a half-maximum rate of phosphorylation at a [CaM]/[MRP] ratio of 0.7, indicating that CaM might efficiently regulate the phosphorylation of MRP in vivo. Interestingly, Ca2+ inhibits the binding of MRP to CaM as well as its phosphorylation by PKM in the millimolar concentration range, suggesting that MRP has a weak affinity for Ca2+. Finally, unmyr MRP can be stoichiometrically myristoylated by N-myristoyl transferase in vitro. Since neither binding of CaM nor phosphorylation by PKM inhibits myristoylation, the N terminus of unmyr MRP is exposed on the surface of the protein and is well separated from the effector domain. In view of the observations that unmyr and myr MRP do not exhibit significant differences in their properties in solution, the function of myristoylation is most probably to modulate the interactions of MRP with membranes.

Cold acclimation of rainbow trout cells is considered to be mediated by alterations in the mRNAs and proteins present in cold-treated cells. A subtracted cDNA library from cold-treated rainbow trout RTG-2 cells was constructed and screened to isolate cDNA induced in the cold-treated cells in order to elucidate which genes are induced by cold acclimation. A set of cDNA clones encoding three members of ferritin H isoforms was isolated as cold-inducible genes. Northern blot analysis and nuclear run-on transcription assay showed that the transcription and accumulation of the ferritin H isoforms mRNA were enhanced by cold acclimation. Furthermore, the ferritin level in the trout cells increased on cold acclimation in response to a temperature shift from 22°C to 4°C. When the trout cells were subjected to 4°C under the condition of a decreased ferritin H level obtained by the addition of an antisense oligonucleotide, cell growth was apparently inhibited. These findings indicate an association between the induction of ferritin H and cellular mechanisms during cold acclimation of trout cells. Northern blot analysis and nuclear run-on transcription assay showed that the transcription and accumulation of the ferritin H isoforms mRNA were enhanced by cold acclimation. Furthermore, the ferritin level in the trout cells increased on cold acclimation in response to a temperature shift from 22°C to 4°C. When the trout cells were subjected to 4°C under the condition of a decreased ferritin H level obtained by the addition of an antisense oligonucleotide, cell growth was apparently inhibited. These findings indicate an association between the induction of ferritin H and cellular mechanisms during cold acclimation of trout cells.

In photoreceptor cells, visual transduction occurs through photoexcitation of rhodopsin, GTP activation of the α subunit of transducin, and interaction between GTP-bound transducin α subunit and the inhibitory γ subunit of phosphodiesterase. The γ subunit of phosphodiesterase, in turn, accelerates the hydrolysis of GTP on the α subunit of transducin. Within the COOH-terminal residues (46-87) of the phosphodiesterase γ subunit, Trp-70 has been implicated in phosphodiesterase activation, transducin α subunit-phosphodiesterase γ subunit interaction, and the GTP hydrolysis accelerating activity. We have derivatized the phosphodiesterase γ subunit with a reversible photoactivatable reagent, [125I]N-[(3-iodo-4-azidophenylpropionamido-S-(2-thiopyridyl)]cysteine ([125I]ACTP), at cysteine (Cys-68). A light-dependent, cross-linked complex of guanosine 5′-(γ-thio)triphosphate-bound transducin α subunit and ACTPderivatized phosphodiesterase γ subunit formed after photolysis of a 1:1 stoichiometic complex of the two proteins. The specificity of complex formation between the transducin α subunit and the phosphodiesterase γ subunit was demonstrated by specific protection by the C68A mutant of the phosphodiesterase γ subunit. The cross-linked complex was treated with β-mercaptoethanol to transfer the 125I photomoiety from the phosphodiesterase γ subunit to the transducin α subunit. Combined techniques involving electrophoresis, chemical and enzymatic cleavage, and chemical and radiosequencing were used to identify photoinsertion sites on the α3 and α4/β6 regions of the transducin α subunit. Three photo-labeled residues, His-244 (α3 helix), Met-308, and Arg-310 (α4/β6 interface), were specifically identified as photoinsertion sites. Utilizing the crystal structure coordinates of the GTP-bound transducin α subunit and molecular modeling, we conclude that Cys-68 of the phosphodiesterase γ subunit is located at a position between the exposed face of the α3 and α4 helices of the transducin α subunit. We propose that the phosphodiesterase γ subunit interacts with GTP-bound transducin α subunit at multiple sites in which the cysteine 68 to tryptophan 70 sequence of the phosphodiesterase γ subunit, which is critical for GTP hydrolysis accelerating activity, interacts in the α3/α4/β6 region of GTP-bound transducin α subunit. In photoreceptor cells, visual transduction occurs through photoexcitation of rhodopsin, GTP activation of the α subunit of transducin, and interaction between GTP-bound transducin α subunit and the inhibitory γ subunit of phosphodiesterase. The γ subunit of phosphodiesterase, in turn, accelerates the hydrolysis of GTP on the α subunit of transducin. Within the COOH-terminal residues (46-87) of the phosphodiesterase γ subunit, Trp-70 has been implicated in phosphodiesterase activation, transducin α subunit-phosphodiesterase γ subunit interaction, and the GTP hydrolysis accelerating activity. We have derivatized the phosphodiesterase γ subunit with a reversible photoactivatable reagent, [125I]N-[(3-iodo-4-azidophenylpropionamido-S-(2-thiopyridyl)]cysteine ([125I]ACTP), at cysteine (Cys-68). A light-dependent, cross-linked complex of guanosine 5′-(γ-thio)triphosphate-bound transducin α subunit and ACTPderivatized phosphodiesterase γ subunit formed after photolysis of a 1:1 stoichiometic complex of the two proteins. The specificity of complex formation between the transducin α subunit and the phosphodiesterase γ subunit was demonstrated by specific protection by the C68A mutant of the phosphodiesterase γ subunit. The cross-linked complex was treated with β-mercaptoethanol to transfer the 125I photomoiety from the phosphodiesterase γ subunit to the transducin α subunit. Combined techniques involving electrophoresis, chemical and enzymatic cleavage, and chemical and radiosequencing were used to identify photoinsertion sites on the α3 and α4/β6 regions of the transducin α subunit. Three photo-labeled residues, His-244 (α3 helix), Met-308, and Arg-310 (α4/β6 interface), were specifically identified as photoinsertion sites. Utilizing the crystal structure coordinates of the GTP-bound transducin α subunit and molecular modeling, we conclude that Cys-68 of the phosphodiesterase γ subunit is located at a position between the exposed face of the α3 and α4 helices of the transducin α subunit. We propose that the phosphodiesterase γ subunit interacts with GTP-bound transducin α subunit at multiple sites in which the cysteine 68 to tryptophan 70 sequence of the phosphodiesterase γ subunit, which is critical for GTP hydrolysis accelerating activity, interacts in the α3/α4/β6 region of GTP-bound transducin α subunit.

LTA cells synthesize a minor population of heparan sulfate proteoglycans (HSPGact) bearing anticoagulant heparan sulfate (HSact) with a specific monosaccharide sequence that accelerates the action of antithrombin (AT). LTA cells also synthesize a major population of heparan sulfate proteoglycans endowed with nonanticoagulant heparan sulfate (HSinact) lacking the AT-binding site. To investigate the pathway-specific features of HSPGact generation, we established a novel detergent-containing cell-free system with unlabeled and labeled microsomes from wild-type and variant LTA cells, respectively. The unlabeled microsomes provide “HSact conversion activity” that requires 3′-phosphoadenosine 5′-phosphosulfate to convert [35S]HSPGinact into [35S] HSPGact, presumably by sulfation. The reaction kinetics demonstrate that the rate of HSact synthesis is constant over the first 4 h of incubation. During this time, the rate of HSact production is linearly dependent on the amount of unlabeled LTA microsomal protein over a range of 10 to 50 μg as well as on the level of [35S]HS substrate over a range of 0.4 to 4.0 μg, microsomal protein. Compared with labeled microsomes, equivalent or slightly greater levels of HSact were generated from 35S-labeled HSPG, microsomal HS, or cell surface HS, which demonstrates that HSinact is the minimal substrate and that large amounts of HSact precursor exit the Golgi apparatus. Indeed, extensive modification of wild-type LTA cell surface [35S]HS elevated HSact content from 9 to 35%. The hypothesis that microsomal HSact conversion activity predicts the cellular rate of HSact generation was tested with wild-type or variant LTA cells in which production of HSact has been significantly altered by mutagenesis or overexpression of core protein or growth conditions. The data demonstrate that microsomal HSact conversion activity accurately reflects the cellular rate of HSact synthesis over a very wide range of conditions. The possibility that the reduced HSact generation is due to an inhibitor was excluded by mixing experiments. The possibility that reduced HSact generation is caused by decreased levels of HSact precursor was excluded as equivalent levels of HSact were formed from wild-type and variant [35S]HS. Based upon the above data, the LTA cell microsomal HSact conversion activity contains one or more limiting components that kinetically regulate the rate of cellular HSact generation and the levels of HSact precursor in HS greatly exceed HSact production. The elucidation of the structure-function relationships for anticoagulant heparin, a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) 1The abbreviations used are: GAG(s)glycosaminoglycan(s)ATantithrombinBSAbovine serum albuminCSchondroitin sulfateHS(PG)heparan sulfate (proteoglycan)HS(PG)actanticoagulant heparan sulfate (proteoglycan)HS(PG)inactnonanticoagulant heparan sulfate (proteoglycan)PAGEpolyacrylamide gel electrophoresisPBSphosphate-buffered salinePG(s)proteoglycan(s)PAPS3′-phosphoadenosine 5′-phosphosulfateMES4-morpholineethanesulfonic acid. of mast cells, has served as a model for discerning the role of anticoagulant heparan sulfate proteoglycans (HSPGact) in the vascular system. The circulating plasma protease inhibitor, antithrombin (AT), neutralizes proteolytic enzymes of the coagulation cascade by slow formation of a binary complex. However, in the presence of heparin, AT binds to a unique oligosaccharide structure and undergoes a conformational change that dramatically accelerates the rate of complex formation (1Rosenberg R.D. The pharmacologic action of heparin exploits a natural anticoagulant mechanism of the blood vessel wall, which is based on the highly specific interaction described above (12Marcum J.A. Rosenberg R.D. Lane D.A. Lindahl U. Heparin, Chemical and Biological Properties: Clinical Applications. Edward Arnold, London1989: 275Google Scholar). Endothelial cells produce HSPGact, a minor subpopulation of heparan sulfate proteoglycans (HSPGs) that accelerate neutralization of coagulation enzymes through the heparan sulfate (HS) component that contains the appropriate oligosaccharide structure to bind AT (HSact) (13Marcum J.A. Atha D.H. Fritze L.M.S. Nawroth P. Stern D. Rosenberg R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 7507-7517Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 14Marcum J.A. McKenney J.B. Rosenberg R.D. J. Clin. Invest. 1984; 74: 341-350Crossref PubMed Scopus (236) Google Scholar). The remaining HSPGs are nonanticoagulant (HSPGinact) and contain HS chains that lack the AT-binding site (HSinact). The demonstration of an HSPG that contains regions of defined monosaccharide sequence that mediate a specific biologic function suggests that a similar situation may exist for other biologic systems. However, unlike the generation of other biopolymers, the ordered assembly of distinct disaccharide units does not involve a simple template, and so it remains unclear how HSPGact is formed. The capacity of the HSPG biosynthetic enzymes to generate HSPGact may stem exclusively from inherent abundance and interactive properties or alternatively could require additional specific interactions with either unique or non-unique core proteins or regulatory factors. However, Kojima et al. (15Kojima T. Shworak N.W. Rosenberg R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4870-4877Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 16Kojima T. Leone C.W. Marchildon G.A. Marcum J.A. Rosenberg R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4859-4869Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) isolated two major endothelial cell HSPGs, ryudocan (syndecan-4) and syndecan-1, and found that both contained HSact and HSinact, which demonstrates that the generation of HSact does not require a single unique core protein. These findings were subsequently extended to fibroglycan, glypican, and perlican isolated from endothelial cells (17Mertens G. Cassiman J.-J. Van den Berghe H. Vermylen J. David G. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 20435-20443Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar); however, it remained conceivable that purified PGs might contain an undetected component with a minor variation in primary sequence that directs generation of HSact. To resolve this issue, Shworak et al. (18Shworak N.W. Shirakawa M. Colliec-Jouault S. Liu J. Mulligan R.C. Birinyi L.K. Rosenberg R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 24941-24952Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) expressed epitope tagged rat ryudocan in LTA cells and early passage endothelial cells, both of which produce HSPGact, isolated the exogenous origin PGs, and demonstrated that a single core protein with a unique primary sequence initiates synthesis of both HSact and HSinact. Furthermore, the expression of mutated forms of epitope tagged ryudocan containing only a single functional GAG acceptor site demonstrates that each of the three acceptor regions initiates synthesis of both forms of HS to a similar degree. We have further examined the functioning of the Golgi biosynthetic machinery by overexpressing epitope tagged ryudocan and determining the extent of synthesis of HSact and HSinact (18Shworak N.W. Shirakawa M. Colliec-Jouault S. Liu J. Mulligan R.C. Birinyi L.K. Rosenberg R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 24941-24952Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The generation of HSPGinact increased linearly as a function of ryudocan expression, which indicates that synthesis of this GAG is limited by the availability of core protein. In striking contrast, the production of HSPGact decreased as a function of ryudocan expression, which suggests that synthesis of this GAG is limited by factors other than core protein. The subsequent data strongly supported the view that increased intracellular levels of ryudocan are responsible for decreased generation of HSPGact. In particular, the reduction in HSPGact production occurred with overexpression of the ryudocan ectodomain, which is directly secreted into the medium, or by a ryudocan form incapable of augmenting the synthesis of GAGs due to mutated attachment sites. However, the suppression in HSPGact production did not appear to involve the direct inhibition of general HS biosynthetic enzymes by core protein as overexpression of ryudocan failed to significantly reduce the size of HSact or HSinact or perturb the structure of HSact and HSinact. On the basis of the above results, we concluded that the increased intracellular levels of ryudocan most probably saturate the capacity of a component that is specific to the HSact biosynthetic pathway. The existence of a pathway-specific component is also supported by the investigation of the chemically mutated LTA cell line, VI-7 (19Colliec-Jouault S. Shworak N.W. Liu J. de Agostini A.I. Rosenberg R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 24953-24958Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Although LTA VI-7 produces normal levels of HSinact, synthesis of HSact is 5-7-fold lower than for wild-type LTA cells. This abnormality is not due to a defect in core protein production as complementation is not observed when mutant LTA cells are transfected with the ryudocan core, which can initiate HSact production. Structural analyses revealed that HSact and HSinact from LTA VI-7 are indistinguishable from wild-type HSact and HSinact, respectively, which indicates that the general HS biosynthetic enzymes were not altered. Together, the analyses of LTA VI-7 and the core protein overexpressing cell line suggest that the production of HSact involves a pathway-specific component that limits the capacity of the general HS biosynthetic enzymes to generate the defined monosaccharide sequence of HSact. If the pathway-specific component limits a single biosynthetic step, then the precursor for this step should be present in excess. The existence of such a precursor should permit the development of a cell-free system that would allow the identification of both the limiting component and the structure of the required precursor. In the present report, we characterize a novel cell-free system that employs microsomal HSact conversion activity to generate HSact from HSinact, and we demonstrate that this microsomal HSact conversion activity predicts cellular HSact production. Thus, we have established an experimental approach for elucidating the pathway-specific features of HSact biosynthesis. The analysis of variant LTA cell lines reveals that HSinact contains an excess pool of molecules that function as a precursor for HSact synthesis. Moreover, the level of HSact production is limited by the activity of one or more microsomal sulfotransferases that modify this precursor population. Shirakawa M. Mulligan R.C. Rosenberg R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 21204-21214Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar).
