Muscle myosins belong to class II of the myosin family (1Mooseker M.S. Cheney R.E. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1995; 11: 633-675Crossref PubMed Scopus (390) Google Scholar). These proteins consist of a pair of heavy chains (HCs), 1The abbreviations used are: HCheavy chainELCessential light chainRLCregulatory light chainshMsingle-headed myosinS1subfragment 1HMMheavy meromyosinMOPS3-(N-morpholino)propanesulfonic acidDTTdithiothreitolTEMEDN,N,N′,N′-tetramethylethylenediamineFTPformycin triphosphate. two ELCs, and two RLCs. Muscle myosins can be divided into three categories depending on the mode of activation by Ca2+. In skeletal muscles contraction occurs after the binding of Ca2+ to the thin filaments, which changes the interactions of the myosin cross-bridges with the actin filaments. In contrast to skeletal muscle myosin, smooth muscle and molluscan myosins are regulated molecules (cf. 2Adelstein R.S. Eisenberg E. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1980; 49: 921-956Crossref PubMed Scopus (745) Google Scholar). Smooth muscle myosin is regulated by phosphorylation of its RLC by a Ca2+-and calmodulin-dependent myosin light chain kinase. Contraction of molluscan muscles is regulated by binding of Ca2+ to myosin. The Ca2+ binding site of molluscan myosins is located in domain I of the ELC and is stabilized by specific contacts between the ELC and both the RLC and the HC (3Xie X. Harrison D.H. Schlichting I. Sweet R.M. Kalabokis V.N. Szent-Györgyi A.G. Cohen C. Nature. 1994; 368: 306-312Crossref PubMed Scopus (266) Google Scholar). The affinity for Ca2+ is preserved in the proteolytic fragments of myosin, regulatory domain, subfragment 1 (S1), and heavy meromyosin (HMM) (4Kwon H. Goodwin E.B. Nyitray L. Berliner E. O'Neall-Hennessey E. Melandri F.D. Szent-Györgyi A.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 4771-4775Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). The structural requirements for the ELC, RLC, and HC that are needed for the formation of the specific Ca2+ binding site have been studied by the construction of hybrids between naturally occurring and mutant LCs and HCs (5Kwon H. Melandri F.D. Szent-Györgyi A.G. J. Muscle Res. Cell Motil. 1992; 13: 315-320Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar, 6Kalabokis V.N. O'Neal-Hennessey E. Szent-Györgyi A.G. J. Muscle Res. Cell Motil. 1994; 15: 547-553Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar, 7Jancso A. Szent-Györgyi A.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 8762-8766Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar, 8Fromherz S. Szent-Györgyi A.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 7652-7656Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). heavy chain essential light chain regulatory light chain single-headed myosin subfragment 1 heavy meromyosin 3-(N-morpholino)propanesulfonic acid dithiothreitol N,N,N′,N′-tetramethylethylenediamine formycin triphosphate. The structural features of the regulated smooth and molluscan muscle myosins that place the molecules in the off state have been studied by examining the properties of three proteolytic fragments of these myosins: S1, HMM, and shM. The single-headed S1 and the double-headed HMM are soluble, whereas shM forms filaments in conditions similar to those of the parent myosin. In contrast to HMMs, S1s derived from smooth and molluscan myosins are not regulated, suggesting a role for the presence of the two heads and/or the coiled coil rod in the regulation of these myosins (9Szent-Györgyi A.G. Szentkiralyi E.M. Kendrick-Jones J. J. Mol. Biol. 1973; 74: 179-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (275) Google Scholar, 10Stafford W.F. Szentkiralyi E. Szent-Györgyi A.G. Biochemistry. 1979; 18: 5273-5380Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar, 11Seidel J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1980; 255: 4355-4361Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The activating effect of Ca2+ on the ATPase activity of mixtures of single- and double-headed scallop myosin (prepared by papain digestion of scallop myosin) indicated that single-headed scallop myosin was regulated by Ca2+, since the increase of the ATPase activity of the preparations could not be attributed entirely to the presence of intact myosin (10Stafford W.F. Szentkiralyi E. Szent-Györgyi A.G. Biochemistry. 1979; 18: 5273-5380Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). It was calculated that Ca2+ increased the ATPase activity of shM by 3-4-fold These experiments supported the notion that the head-rod junction of molluscan myosins has an important role in regulation (10Stafford W.F. Szentkiralyi E. Szent-Györgyi A.G. Biochemistry. 1979; 18: 5273-5380Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). Recently, Cremo et al. (12Cremo C.R. Sellers J.R. Facemyer K.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 270: 2171-2175Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (89) Google Scholar) obtained a pure single-headed smooth muscle myosin preparation, which was fully active in the absence of phosphorylation, showing that only the two-headed smooth muscle myosins are regulated molecules. A similar conclusion was reached from studies of expressed smooth muscle HMMs with short rod domains of different lengths that enabled them to exist in equilibrium between a monomeric and a dimeric form (13Trybus K.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20819-20822Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In this article we report the purification and properties of a single-headed scallop myosin preparation. The data suggest that the presence of both heads and the attachment of the head to the coiled coil contribute to the “off” state of scallop myosin. Scallop myosin was prepared from the striated adductor muscle of Argopecten irradians as described previously (10Stafford W.F. Szentkiralyi E. Szent-Györgyi A.G. Biochemistry. 1979; 18: 5273-5380Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). It was suspended in 140 mM NaCl, 20 mM MOPS, 2 mM MgCl2, 0.2 mM CaCl2, 0.1 mM EDTA, and 0.5 mM DTT, pH 7, at 6-10 mg/ml and digested with affinity-purified papain (14Funk M.O. Nakagawa Y. Skochdopole J. Kaiser E.T. Int. J. Pept. Protein Res. 1979; 13: 296-303Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar) for 20 min at 20°C, using a w/w ratio of myosin/papain of 2000. The digestion was stopped by adding leupeptin to 20 μg/ml, and the sample was diluted with 4 volumes of ice-cold water. The filaments were pelleted and washed three times by centrifugation in 40 mM NaCl, 5 mM Pi, 1 mM MgCl2, 0.1 mM EDTA, 3 mM NaN3, 0.5 mM DTT, and 5 μg/ml leupeptin, pH 7. Then MOPS was added to 20 mM, MgCl2 to 5 mM, and ATP to 0.5 mM, the pH was adjusted to 7, and the filaments were solubilized by the addition of NaCl to 0.6 M. The sample was clarified by centrifugation at 40,000 × g for 30 min, and the supernatant was diluted slowly with an equal volume of a solution containing 3 M ammonium sulfate, 40 mM MOPS, 10 mM MgCl2, 0.4 mM CaCl2, 0.2 mM EDTA, 0.4 mM ATP, and 1 mM DTT, pH 6.8, and the sample (∼150 mg) was applied to a 25-ml column of Toyopearl ether 650 S (TosoHaas), equilibrated in 1.5 M ammonium sulfate, 20 mM MOPS, 5 mM MgCl2, 0.2 mM CaCl2, 0.1 mM EDTA, 0.2 mM ATP, and 0.5 mM DTT, pH 6.8. Bound proteins were eluted with an 800-ml gradient of ammonium sulfate from 1.5 to 1 M. An aliquot of the collected fractions was dialyzed against 40 mM NaCl, 5 mM Pi, 0.1 mM EDTA, 1 mM MgCl2, 3 mM NaN3, and 0.5 mM DTT and analyzed by native gel electrophoresis. Fractions containing shM were pooled and dialyzed against 40 mM NaCl, 5 mM Pi, 1 mM MgCl2, 0.1 mM EDTA, 0.5 mM DTT, and 3 mM NaN3, pH 7, and the formed filaments were collected by centrifugation and suspended in the same buffer. Native 4% polyacrylamide gels were prepared by polymerizing a solution of 4% acrylamide, 0.1% bisacrylamide, 10% glycerol, 10 mM sodium pyrophosphate, 3.3 mM TEMED, pH 9, by the addition of ammonium persulfate to 0.33 mM. Prior to electrophoresis the samples were solubilized by the addition of an equal volume of 40% glycerol, 20 mM sodium pyrophosphate, pH 9. The electrophoresis buffer contained 10% glycerol and 10 mM sodium pyrophosphate, pH 9, and was circulated from the lower to the upper electrophoresis chamber with the aid of a peristaltic pump. Gel electrophoresis in the presence of SDS was performed according to Laemmli (15Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (207538) Google Scholar). Ca2+ binding measurements with myosin and shM were carried out as described previously (16Chantler P.D. Sellers J.R. Szent-Györgyi A.G. Biochemistry. 1981; 20: 473-492Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar) at 22°C in a medium containing 40 mM KCl, 20 mM MOPS, 10 mM MgCl2, 3 mM NaN3, 0.5 mM DTT, 0.1 mM [45Ca]CaCl2, and various concentrations of EGTA to obtain the desired free Ca2+ concentration at pH 7.0. Free Ca2+ concentrations were calculated with a program that uses an iterative procedure (17Chantler P.D. Szent-Györgyi A.G. J. Mol. Biol. 1980; 138: 473-492Crossref PubMed Scopus (129) Google Scholar) taking into account the amount of contaminating Ca2+ (5 μM). Myosin or shM were suspended at 4 mg/ml, in 40 mM KCl, 20 mM MOPS, 10 mM MgCl2, 0.5 mM DTT, 3 mM NaN3, and 0.1 mM CaCl2 or 1 mM EGTA, pH 7.0. [γ-32P]ATP was mixed with myosin or shM at 4 mg/ml, and 10 s later 200 μl of the sample was diluted with 4 ml of buffer also containing 0.1 mM unlabeled ATP and 0.1 mM Pi. At various time intervals a 600-μl aliquot was filtered on a Millipore 0.45-μm filter type HA, and the filter was washed with 4 ml of the buffer. The filter was then removed and counted. The filaments were retained quantitatively on the filter. The duration of the filtration and washing was 20-30 s. Samples of myosin or shM were diluted to about 15 μg/ml in a spraying buffer containing 30% (by volume) 1 M ammonium acetate, 1 mM MgCl2, 0.1 mM EGTA, and 70% glycerol. They were sprayed onto mica and rotary shadowed with platinum as described previously (18Flicker P.F. Wallimann T.A. Vibert P. J. Mol. Biol. 1983; 169: 723-741Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar). Electron micrographs were recorded at a 50,000 × magnification in a Philips EM301 electron microscope. The rate of ATP hydrolysis was measured with the coupled assay method (19Bergmeyer H. Methods of Enzymic Analysis. Academic Press, New York1965: 10Google Scholar) or by quantitating the amount of inorganic Pi according to the method of Taussky and Shorr (20Taussky H.H. Shorr E. J. Biol. Chem. 1952; 202: 675-685Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar). Both methods gave identical results. The digestion of scallop myosin with papain was stopped when 75-90% of the myosin heads were clipped by papain. Attempts to purify shM from the mixture of scallop myosin, shM, and rods by binding of shM and myosin to filamentous actin, coupled with selective displacement of shM, according to the method developed by Cooke and Franks (21Cooke R. Franks K.E. J. Mol. Biol. 1978; 120: 361-373Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar), were unsuccessful, because the procedure inactivated the ATPase activity of scallop actomyosin and acto-shM. The products of the proteolytic digest were separated by hydrophobic interaction chromatography under native conditions. The mixture of rods, shM, and myosin was made to 1.5 M in ammonium sulfate before it was loaded to a Toyopearl ether 650 S column. At this concentration of ammonium sulfate the rods were partly retained on the column, whereas shM and myosin bound quantitatively. Higher concentrations of ammonium sulfate were not used to avoid precipitation of proteins. The shM did not elute as a single peak and was partly overlapped by rods and myosin. However, fractions highly enriched in shM could be obtained, as shown in Fig. 1. The preparations of shM contained equimolar amounts of intact heavy chains, polypeptides of rod chains, RLCs, and ELCs (Fig. 1). Eleven residues were clipped from the N terminus of the RLC (3Xie X. Harrison D.H. Schlichting I. Sweet R.M. Kalabokis V.N. Szent-Györgyi A.G. Cohen C. Nature. 1994; 368: 306-312Crossref PubMed Scopus (266) Google Scholar), which usually occurs during prolonged digestions of scallop myosin with papain (Fig. 1). In addition to the electrophoretic pattern in native gels, electron microscopy provided strong evidence that the isolated product was shM. The electron micrographs of shM preparations showed a single head attached to a rod of the same diameter as that of the double-headed conventional myosins (Fig. 2), in good agreement with the electrophoretic pattern of shM.Fig. 2Rotary shadowed electron microscopic pictures of myosin and single-headed myosin. Both molecules show the presence of a rod domain. Two heads are attached to the rod of myosin (A), whereas only one head can be seen attached to the rod of shM (B). No difference is seen between the rods of the two myosins.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) The ATPase activity of shM was not as tightly regulated as the activity of intact myosin. Although the ATPase activity of shM was comparable with that of intact myosin (per head) in the presence of Ca2+, the activity in the presence of EGTA was considerably higher. This resulted in a reduced Ca2+ sensitivity of 60-70% (percentage of Ca2+ sensitivity = (1 − ATPase rate + EGTA/ATPase rate + Ca2+) × 100) in shM. The activities of various shM preparations were in the range 0.4-0.7 s−1 in the absence of actin. Actin activated the ATPase activity of shM 2-3-fold. These activities and the degree of actin activation were comparable with those of the starting myosin preparation. Undigested myosin that was recovered from the hydrophobic column also maintained its ATPase activity during the treatment and suffered a small loss in its Ca2+ sensitivity, which was decreased from ∼97 to ∼87%. Therefore, the lower Ca2+ sensitivity of shM relative to that of control myosin cannot be attributed entirely to the experimental treatment. Preparations of scallop myosin contain varying amounts of unregulated heads, probably due to the experimental manipulation of the protein, which have high activity in the presence of EGTA. Therefore, the degree of regulation of scallop myosin and shM is underestimated by ATPase activities. Myosin was activated by Ca2+ in a highly cooperative fashion, as was found previously under somewhat different ionic conditions (16Chantler P.D. Sellers J.R. Szent-Györgyi A.G. Biochemistry. 1981; 20: 473-492Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). In contrast, the Ca2+-activated ATPase activity of shM showed a hyperbolic dependence on the concentration of free Ca2+, with half-maximal activation at 0.09 μM Ca2+ (Fig. 3). Thus, the highly cooperative activation of the scallop myosin by Ca2+, which displays Hill coefficients as high as 5 (16Chantler P.D. Sellers J.R. Szent-Györgyi A.G. Biochemistry. 1981; 20: 473-492Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar), is related to the double-headed nature of myosin. The Ca2+ binding of myosin and shM was examined in a medium containing 40 mM KCl, 20 mM MOPS, 10 mM MgCl2, 3 mM NaN3, 0.5 mM DTT, and various concentrations of free Ca2+ at pH 7.0. Myosin and shM bound Ca2+ stoichiometrically to their head content with association constants of 5 × 106 and 11 × 106M−1, respectively (Fig. 3). The activation of the ATPase activity of shM by Ca2+ paralleled closely the saturation of its specific Ca2+ binding site by Ca2+ (Fig. 3), indicating a correlation between the two phenomena. The 3-fold activation of the ATPase activity of shM by Ca2+ can be attributed either to the presence of two populations of molecules, one highly regulated and one unregulated, as is the case with scallop HMM (22Wells C. Bagshaw C.R. FEBS Lett. 1984; 168: 260-264Crossref Scopus (18) Google Scholar), or to a single population of molecules with enzymatic properties that have been altered. To settle this question we carried out single turnover experiments with [γ-32P]ATP. The radioactive ATP was mixed with myosin or shM, and after stopping the hydrolysis of [γ-32P]ATP with an excess of cold ATP (see “Experimental Procedures”), an aliquot of the reaction was filtered and washed on the filter. Since the filter retains filaments quantitatively, the radioactivity associated with the filter is proportional to the amount of labeled ATP and ADP-32Pi remaining at the active sites. The results of these experiments are shown in Fig. 4. In the presence of EGTA the release of phosphate from the active site of myosin followed first order kinetic behavior with a rate constant of 0.22 min−1. When the filter was washed with buffer containing 0.1 mM CaCl2 instead of 1 mM EGTA, the radioactivity remaining on the filter decreased to background levels. This control experiment indicated that the filtration did not damage scallop myosin, since although bound to the filter, the molecule maintained its ability to be activated by Ca2+. Fig. 4 also shows that the concentration of intermediates having bound Pi at the active site increased with the concentration of [γ-32P]ATP at ratios of ATP/myosin heads of greater than 1. In the presence of Ca2+ the same reaction was too fast to measure with this method, which has a resolution time of ∼30 s. In contrast to myosin, the release of Pi from the active site of shM in the presence of EGTA was also too fast to be measured with this method, suggesting that the proteolytic removal of one of the myosin heads alters the enzymatic properties of the remaining head.Fig. 4Single turnovers of myosin and single-headed myosin with [γ-32P]ATP. The rates of Pi release were 0.22 and 0.23 min−1, with 10- and 1.2-fold molar excesses of ATP to myosin heads, respectively. There was a 10-fold (×) molar excess of [γ-32P]ATP to myosin heads in the presence of Ca2+. ▪, amount of radioactivity remaining on the filter when myosin, treated with a 10-fold molar excess of [γ-32P]ATP to myosin heads in the presence of EGTA, was filtered and washed with buffer containing 0.1 mM CaCl2 instead of 1 mM EGTA. Single-headed myosin (8.5 μM) reacted with a 10-fold molar excess of [γ-32P]ATP (85 μM) in the presence of Ca2+ (▴) or in the presence of EGTA (▵). The high turnover rate of shM in the presence of EGTA (typical values were 0.2-0.3 s−1) did not allow for the measurement of the rate of Pi release with this method, which has a resolution time of ∼30 s.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) The electrophoretic profiles and the electron microscopic observations of the single-headed scallop myosin preparation showed that the isolated protein was highly purified, containing at least 97% shM. The RLC of the shM was partly clipped by papain. When the RLC of myosin is replaced by the papain-clipped RLC, the hybrid myosin maintains the activity and degree of regulation of the parent myosin (23Sellers J.R. Chantler P.D. Szent-Györgyi A.G. J. Mol. Biol. 1980; 144: 223-245Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). Thus, the decreased Ca2+ sensitivity of the single-headed scallop myosin preparation cannot be attributed to the modification of its RLC. On addition of Ca2+, the ATPase activity of the single-headed scallop myosin was increased about 3-fold, both in the presence and absence of actin. A similar degree of activation of the ATPase activity of shM by Ca2+ was calculated from the effect of Ca2+ on the actin-activated ATPase activity of mixtures of myosin and shM (10Stafford W.F. Szentkiralyi E. Szent-Györgyi A.G. Biochemistry. 1979; 18: 5273-5380Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). The Ca2+ activation of the ATPase activity of shM paralleled closely the saturation of its specific Ca2+ binding site, indicating a correlation between the two phenomena. The absence of an activating effect of Ca2+ on the ATPase activity of scallop S1 (9Szent-Györgyi A.G. Szentkiralyi E.M. Kendrick-Jones J. J. Mol. Biol. 1973; 74: 179-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (275) Google Scholar, 10Stafford W.F. Szentkiralyi E. Szent-Györgyi A.G. Biochemistry. 1979; 18: 5273-5380Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar) suggests that the attachment of the head to the coiled coil rod establishes a “communication” between the Ca2+ binding site and the ATPase site. In contrast to shM, Ca2+ activates the ATPase activity of scallop myosin cooperatively. The Hill coefficient for the activation of the scallop myosin ATPase by Ca2+ is usually greater than 4 (16Chantler P.D. Sellers J.R. Szent-Györgyi A.G. Biochemistry. 1981; 20: 473-492Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). The hyperbolic dependence of the Ca2+-activated ATPase activity of shM on the concentration of free Ca2+ indicates that the cooperativity seen with scallop myosin requires the presence of its two heads. The behavior of shM in regulation is between the fully regulated intact myosin and the unregulated S1. The interaction of a single head with the coiled coil rod confers to it a limited form of regulation, which lacks the cooperative features of the fully regulated double-headed myosin. Nevertheless, it clearly shows Ca2+ dependence that is not observed in S1. To explain the slow turnover rates of scallop myosin and scallop HMM in the presence of EGTA, Jackson and Bagshaw (24Jackson A.P. Bagshaw C.R. Biochem. J. 1988; 251: 527-540Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar) proposed the following scheme (Scheme I) that was based on the results of single turnover experiments of the regulated scallop HMM with the ATP analogue FTP. They suggested that in the presence of EGTA the rate constants k3 and k+r are comparable, whereas k−r≪ k3 or k+r. This leads to accumulation of M*FDP.Pi (refractory state) which cannot release Pi. Ca2+ shifts the equilibrium toward MFDP.Pi, which releases Pi fast, thereby increasing the rate of ATP hydrolysis. M∗ FDP.P iM+FTPk1k−1MFTPFastMFDP.Pik3M+PrSCHEME I From Jackson and Bagshaw (24Jackson A.P. Bagshaw C.R. Biochem. J. 1988; 251: 527-540Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). k+1 = 2 × 105 M−11 s−1≫ k−1; k3 = 0.15 s−1; k+r≫ k−r. We used filtration to measure the concentration of intermediates with ATP and ADP-Pi at the active site in single turnover experiments of scallop myosin and shM. This method is suitable for samples of myosin in the filamentous state and gives good signal/noise ratio, and the physiological substrate (ATP) can be used. The single turnovers of scallop myosin with [γ-32P]ATP provided further support for the presence of a refractory state (24Jackson A.P. Bagshaw C.R. Biochem. J. 1988; 251: 527-540Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar), since the amount of Pi bound at the ATPase site increased with the concentration of ATP with ratios of ATP/myosin heads of greater than 1. This is what would be expected with an excess of ATP over myosin heads according to Scheme I. The molecules in the MADP.Pi conformation that will not isomerize into the refractory state will release the products of ATP hydrolysis and go through another cycle. The refractory state (M*ADP.Pi) accumulates because k+r≫ k−r. The absence of a slow phase of Pi release from shM suggests that the 3-fold activation of the ATPase activity of shM by Ca2+ was not due to the presence of two populations of molecules, i.e. one regulated with properties similar to those of myosin and one unregulated that has high ATPase activity in the presence of EGTA. The data are consistent with a homogeneous shM preparation with enzymatic properties different from those of myosin. The activating effect of Ca2+ can be explained by: (i) a decrease in the value of the equilibrium constant for the refractory state (Scheme I) in the presence of Ca2+; or (ii) an effect of Ca2+ on the rate of product release from MADP.Pi. The resolution time (∼30 s) of the single turnover measurements did not allow for distinguishing between these possibilities. The regulation of shM cannot be explained by head-to-head interactions. The communication between the Ca2+ binding site, which is formed by the light chains, and the nucleotide binding site of the motor domain is probably affected by the head-rod junction, since scallop S1 is unregulated. An interaction of the two heads of scallop myosin, possibly between the LCs, may be sufficient to account for the cooperative activation of scallop myosin by Ca2+ and its greater degree of regulation than that of shM. The data presented in this article suggest that both the double-headed nature of myosin and the attachment of the head to the coiled coil rod contribute to the “off” state of scallop myosin. The coiled coil rod seems to have a less important role in the regulation of smooth muscle myosin, since single-headed smooth muscle myosin is not activated by phosphorylation (12Cremo C.R. The actin-activated Mg2+-ATPase activities of the myosin I isoenzymes from Acanthamoeba castellanii are greatly increased by phosphorylation catalyzed by myosin I heavy chain kinase (MIHC kinase), a monomeric 97-kDa protein whose activity is greatly enhanced by acidic phospholipids and by autophosphorylation of multiple sites. In this paper, we show that the 35-kDa COOH-terminal fragment obtained by trypsin cleavage of maximally activated, autophosphorylated kinase retains the full activity and two to three of the autophosphorylation sites of the native enzyme. Other autophosphorylation sites occur in the middle third of the native enzyme. A trypsin cleavage site within the 35-kDa region is protected in phosphorylated kinase but is readily cleaved in unphosphorylated kinase producing catalytically inactive 25- and 11-kDa fragments from the NH2- and COOH-terminal ends, respectively, of the 35-kDa peptide. This implies that the conformation around the “25/11” cleavage site changes upon phosphorylation of the native enzyme. The position of this site corresponds to the activation loop of protein kinase A (see the accompanying paper: Brzeska, H., Szczepanowska, J., Hoey, J., and Korn, E. D. (1996) J. Biol. Chem. 271, 27056-27062). Exogenously added MIHC kinase phosphorylates the 11-kDa fragment, but not the 25-kDa fragment, indicating that the phosphorylation sites of the 35-kDa catalytic fragment are located within the COOH-terminal 11 kDa. The accompanying paper describes the cloning, sequencing, and expression of a fully active 35-kDa catalytic domain. Acanthamoeba MIHC kinase is a 97-kDa monomer whose activity is regulated in vitro by several factors that have important physiological roles for other kinases (for review, see 8Brzeska H. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 16983-16986Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). Highly purified MIHC kinase autophosphorylates (intermolecularly) slowly; incorporation of 7-8 mol of phosphate/mol of kinase enhances its activity over 50-fold (18Brzeska H. Lynch T.J. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 3591-3594Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and phosphorylation can reach 16 mol/mol. Association of MIHC kinase with acidic phospholipids (18Brzeska H. Lynch T.J. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 3591-3594Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 19Wang Z.Y. Brzeska H. Baines I.C. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 27969-27976Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar) or isolated plasma membranes (20Kulesza-Lipka D. Brzeska H. Baines I.C. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 17995-18001Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) enhances the rate of phosphorylation of myosin I and of autophosphorylation of kinase (∼20-fold). These stimulatory effects of phospholipid are Ca2+-independent but are inhibited by Ca2+-calmodulin (21Brzeska H. Kulesza-Lipka D. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 23870-23875Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), probably because Ca2+-calmodulin and acidic phospholipids compete for the same binding site on the kinase. The roles and locations of the multiple autophosphorylation sites and how the different regulatory factors affect the conformation, and hence the activity, of the kinase molecule are not known. Previous studies involving limited proteolysis by chymotrypsin showed that binding of both acidic phospholipid and Ca2+-calmodulin to MIHC kinase is greatly reduced by removal of the NH2-terminal 7 kDa of the polypeptide (21Brzeska H. Kulesza-Lipka D. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 23870-23875Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 22Brzeska H. Martin B. Kulesza-Lipka D. Baines I.C. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4949-4956Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and that a 54-kDa COOH-terminal fragment (F54) retains the full kinase activity and 3-4 of the ∼11 phosphorylation sites of the native enzyme. Just as for the native MIHC kinase, the activity of F54 is greatly enhanced by autophosphorylation; however, the rate of autophosphorylation of F54 is the same in the presence and absence of phospholipid and comparable with that of native kinase in the presence of phospholipid (22Brzeska H. Martin B. Kulesza-Lipka D. Baines I.C. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4949-4956Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). These results suggest the presence of at least two, sequentially separated, regulatory regions: the acidic phospholipid (plasma membrane)/Ca2+-calmodulin-binding NH2 terminus and the autophosphorylatable, catalytic COOH terminus. In this paper, we report that a 35-kDa fragment obtained by tryptic proteolysis of fully phosphorylated MIHC kinase retains complete catalytic activity and three phosphorylation sites. The conformation of the 35-kDa region depends on the state of kinase phosphorylation with an internal site accessible to trypsin only when the kinase is not phosphorylated. In the accompanying paper (23Brzeska H. Szczepanowska J. Hoey J. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 27056-27062Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar), we utilize the partial amino acid sequences of the tryptic peptides to clone the cDNA corresponding to F35, obtain its sequence, and utilize a baculovirus vector to express a 35 kDa peptide (the catalytic domain) that is as active as native kinase. MIHC kinase was purified as described previously (21Brzeska H. Kulesza-Lipka D. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 23870-23875Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 24Lynch T.J. Brzeska H. Baines I.C. Korn E.D. Methods Enzymol. 1990; 196: 12-23Crossref Scopus (18) Google Scholar) and stored in kinase storage buffer (20 mM Tris, pH 7.5, 50 mM KCl, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 0.01% NaN3) at −20°C. Kinase activity was measured (25Brzeska H. Lynch T.J. Martin B. Corigliano-Murphy A. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 16138-16144Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) using as substrate synthetic peptide PC9, which corresponds to the phosphorylation site of myosin IC. All kinase assays were performed in buffer containing 2.5 mM [γ-32P]ATP (20-40 cpm/pmol), 3.5 mM MgCl2, 50 mM imidazole, pH 7.0, 1 mM EGTA, and 0.2 mg/ml of bovine serum albumin at 20°C for 1 min with a PC9 concentration of 0.2 mM. MIHC kinase and its tryptic cleavage fragments were autophosphorylated in the same buffer at 30°C with an ATP specific activity of 200-400 cpm/pmol. Proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE and incorporation of 32P was measured by liquid scintillation counting of solubilized, excised bands (22Brzeska H. Martin B. Kulesza-Lipka D. Baines I.C. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4949-4956Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), or by scanning autoradiograms of gels which included 32P-labeled protein standards. Tryptic fragments were separated by SDS-PAGE, transferred to Immobilon PSQ membrane (Millipore), and sequenced on an Applied Biosystem model 470A sequenator equipped with on-line model 120A phenylthiohydantoin analyzer (22Brzeska H. Martin B. Kulesza-Lipka D. Baines I.C. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4949-4956Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The transfer buffer was 25 mM Tris, 192 mM glycine, pH 8.3, 0.01% SDS. A polyclonal antibody (α11K) against a synthetic peptide corresponding to the NH2-terminal sequence of F11 (ASVVGTTYWMAPEVV, see “Results,” synthesized using the MAP resin technology to increase the immunogenic response) was raised in rabbits by Research Genetics; its titer against synthetic peptide was greater than 1:500,000 by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. For immunoblots, proteins and peptide fragments were separated by SDS-PAGE transferred to nitrocellulose and incubated with antibodies. Goat anti-rabbit peroxidase-conjugated IgG (Calbiochem) was used as second antibody. Unphosphorylated MIHC kinase (97 kDa) was rapidly cleaved by trypsin to four major fragments of approximate masses of 90, 66, 60, and 11 kDa and three minor fragments of 75, 45, and 35 kDa (Fig. 1, Coomassie, 2 and 5 min). By 30 min, all of these fragments had almost disappeared, except for the 11-kDa fragment which became stronger, and a doublet at 36 and 38 kDa and a prominent band at 25 kDa had appeared. The 25- and 11-kDa fragments were resistant to further proteolysis and became the major products by 60 min. Trypsin cleavage of fully phosphorylated kinase, which, as reported previously (18Brzeska H. Lynch T.J. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 3591-3594Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), had a higher apparent mass by SDS-PAGE (107 kDa) than the unphosphorylated kinase, produced a similar pattern of large fragments (90, 75, 66, and 60 kDa) at short incubation times (Fig. 1, Coomassie, 2 and 5 min), but of slightly slower electrophoretic mobilities as expected for phosphorylated peptides. However, bands corresponding to the 45- and 11-kDa fragments from unphosphorylated kinase were not present (Fig. 1, 2 and 5 min). At longer digestion times of the phosphorylated kinase, a diffuse doublet of 36 and 38 kDa appeared (which is seen more clearly by autoradiography, Fig. 1, 32P) and a stable fragment of 35 kDa accumulated (Fig. 1). All fragments derived from phosphorylated MIHC kinase were phosphorylated (Fig. 1, 32P). The NH2-terminal amino acid sequences of the 90-, 66-, 60-, and 38-kDa fragments derived from unphosphorylated kinase were the same as the NH2-terminal sequences of the corresponding phosphorylated fragments (Table I). Thus, the latter were almost certainly the phosphorylated counterparts of the former. Open table in a new tab Phosphorylated F66 and F60 were consistently degraded much more slowly than unphosphorylated F66 and F60 and persisted until at least 90 min (Fig. 1); a slightly slower rate of degradation was also observed for phosphorylated F90. There was no counterpart of phosphorylated F35 in the final tryptic products of unphosphorylated kinase. Conversely, tryptic digests of phosphorylated kinase never contained F25 or F11 that were the major stable products of tryptic digestion of unphosphorylated kinase. Although the relative amounts of the larger fragments varied in different experiments, the final products were always the same irrespective of the length of the digestion and with up to eight times more trypsin, i.e. F35 was always obtained from phosphorylated kinase and F25 and F11 from unphosphorylated kinase. The different NH2-terminal sequences of phosphorylated F90, F66, and F60 (Table I) suggest that they were derived from MIHC kinase by progressive cleavages at the NH2 terminus; each may, or may not, extend to the COOH terminus of the native kinase (Fig. 2, lower). The NH2-terminal sequence of F38 (Table I) was the same as that of F66, which indicates that F38 was derived from the NH2 terminus of F66 (Fig. 2, lower left). This line of reasoning makes it most likely that F35, the final, stable digestion product of phosphorylated kinase whose NH2-terminal sequence differed from those of all of the larger fragments (Table I), was derived from the COOH-terminal end of MIHC kinase (Fig. 2, lower left). The NH2-terminal sequence of unphosphorylated F25 was identical to that of phosphorylated F35 and the NH2-terminal sequence of unphosphorylated F11 differed from those of all of the other fragments of phosphorylated or unphosphorylated kinase (Table I). Therefore, it seems highly likely that F25 and F11 represented the NH2- and COOH-terminal segments, respectively, of F35 (Fig. 2, lower right). The assignments based on the NH2-terminal sequences were supported by immunoblots of SDS-PAGE gels (Fig. 3). Antibody α11K, which was raised against a 15-residue synthetic peptide corresponding to the NH2-terminal sequence of F11, recognized F35 (Fig. 3, lane d) and F11 (Fig. 3, lane b), but not F25 (Fig. 3, lane b), consistent with F11 originating from the COOH-terminal region of F35. The antibody also recognized intact kinase (Fig. 3, lanes a and c), traces of F90 (Fig. 3, lanes b), F66 and F60 (Fig. 3, lanes b and d). These latter results support the conclusion that F90, F66, and F60 were produced by progressive cleavages at the NH2 terminus of MIHC kinase and contained most, if not all, of the COOH-terminal 35-kDa region of the kinase. Both F66 and F60 were more resistant to proteolysis when derived from phosphorylated kinase, but the most striking effect of phosphorylation was the difference in the final digestion products, i.e. COOH-terminal F35 from phosphorylated kinase and F25 and F11 from unphosphorylated kinase. Thus, phosphorylation strongly inhibits proteolysis at a site about 11 kDa from the COOH terminus. More detailed analysis of the data in Fig. 1, Fig. 2, Fig. 3 provides additional evidence for the greater susceptibility to proteolysis of the COOH terminus of unphosphorylated kinase. For example, F45, which occurred early in the digestion of unphosphorylated kinase (Fig. 1, 2 and 5 min) but was not seen in the digestion of phosphorylated kinase, was not recognized by α11K (Fig. 3, lane b), indicating that it lacks the COOH-terminal 11-kDa region. Also, sequence data suggest that the COOH terminus of F66 derived from unphosphorylated kinase, but not of F66 derived from phosphorylated kinase, is cleaved during extensive incubation with trypsin (see Table I, Footnote a). We reported previously (24Lynch T.J. Brzeska H. Baines I.C. Korn E.D. Methods Enzymol. 1990; 196: 12-23Crossref Scopus (18) Google Scholar) that chymotrypsin digestion produces a 54-kDa peptide from the COOH terminus of both phosphorylated and unphosphorylated MIHC kinase and that F54 retains full catalytic activity and approximately four autophosphorylation sites that must be phosphorylated for maximal enzymatic activity. As the 35-kDa tryptic peptide should be contained within the 54-kDa chymotryptic peptide, it was of interest to determine whether F35, F25, and/or F11 were catalytically active. This was difficult to determine in digestion mixtures such as those shown in Fig. 1, because even after prolonged incubations, these still contained a number of larger fragments that would be expected to have enzymatic activity. To avoid this problem, we employed a two-step digestion procedure, chymotrypsin followed by trypsin (Fig. 2, upper). As expected, chymotrypsin cleaved phosphorylated kinase (Fig. 4, lanes a) to F54 (Fig. 4, lanes b) which was cleaved by trypsin to F35 (Fig. 4, lanes c) that had identical SDS-PAGE mobility as F35 obtained by direct trypsin cleavage of phosphorylated kinase (Fig. 4, lanes d). The only difference was that the F35 obtained by two-step cleavage, like its 54-kDa precursor, appeared as a closely spaced doublet (Fig. 4, lanes c), probably, as suggested previously (22Brzeska H. Martin B. Kulesza-Lipka D. Baines I.C. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4949-4956Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), because of partial chymotryptic cleavage at the COOH terminus. The F35 obtained by single step trypsin cleavage was more heavily contaminated by F66, F60, and the F36/F38 doublet, as is most easily seen on the autoradiogram (Fig. 4, lanes d). The kinase activities of F54 and F35 produced by sequential chymotrypsin and trypsin digestion were significantly higher than the activity of native, phosphorylated kinase (Table II). The apparently still higher activity of F35 obtained by direct trypsin digestion may reflect a contribution from the contaminating larger fragments. Open table in a new tab The analogous experiment with unphosphorylated kinase is shown in Fig. 5. Trypsin digestion of F54 of the initial chymotrypsin digestion (Fig. 5, lane b) produced an amount of F25 (Fig. 5, lane c) comparable with that obtained by direct trypsin cleavage of native kinase (Fig. 5, lanes e and f). However, only a relatively small amount of F11 was obtained in the two-step digestion (Fig. 5, compare lane c with lanes e and f) perhaps, at least in part, because the 54-kDa fragment is probably a mixture of two peptides with identical NH2 termini, but differing slightly at their COOH-terminal ends (22Brzeska H. Martin B. Kulesza-Lipka D. Baines I.C. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4949-4956Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Also, if F11 is stabilized by interaction with other peptides, it might be less stable to trypsin when produced from F54 in the two-step procedure than when it is produced directly from native kinase. As expected, the enzymatic activity of unphosphorylated kinase was quite low, while the activity of the F54 derived from it was equivalent to that of the F54 obtained from phosphorylated kinase (Table II). This is because, as shown previously (22Brzeska H. Martin B. Kulesza-Lipka D. Baines I.C. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4949-4956Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), F54 autophosphorylates much more rapidly than native kinase (in the absence of phospholipid) and thus becomes fully active very early in the assay of its ability to phosphorylate substrate. No kinase activity was detected when the digestion mixture containing F25 derived from unphosphorylated F54 was incubated with PC9. As mentioned, all of the products of trypsin digestion of phosphorylated kinase that were detected by Coomassie Blue were phosphorylated (Fig. 1). The strong intensity on the autoradiogram of the F36/F38 doublet relative to its staining by Coomassie Blue (Fig. 1, 30, 60, and 90 min; Fig. 4, lanes d) indicates that those fragments were highly phosphorylated. F38 has the same NH2-terminal sequence as F66 (Table I). Therefore, if, as we have deduced above, the NH2 terminus of F66 originates from a position about 31 kDa from the NH2 terminus of the native kinase, the highly phosphorylated F38 would originate from approximately the middle third of the molecule. The autoradiogram of the digest of phosphorylated kinase shows that F35, which is derived from the COOH-terminal third of the native kinase, is phosphorylated (Fig. 1, Fig. 2, Fig. 3, Fig. 4). When a digestion mixture obtained by one-step cleavage of unphosphorylated kinase, in which F25 and F11 were the main components, was incubated with [γ-32P]ATP, F11 was phosphorylated and its electrophoretic mobility decreased (Fig. 1, 60+ATP; Fig. 5, lane g), but 32P was not incorporated into F25. As would be expected, F60 and the F36/F38 doublet were also labeled (Fig. 5, lane g). The same results were obtained when the digestion mixture was incubated with fully active, phosphorylated native kinase, F11 became heavily labeled with only traces of radioactivity incorporated into F25 (data not shown). Thus, the autophosphorylation site(s) in the COOH-terminal third of the kinase molecule are, most likely, exclusively in the COOH-terminal 11 kDa region. Only traces of 32P were incorporated into F11 when the products of the two-step digestion of unphosphorylated kinase were incubated with [γ-32P]ATP (Fig. 5, lane d), in agreement with the observation that this mixture lacks significant kinase activity (Table II). The phosphate contents of F54, F35, F25, and F11 were quantified from the experiments illustrated in Figs. 1, 4, and 5. Intact kinase was autophosphorylated to the extent of 16 mol/mol. F54 derived from autophosphorylated kinase retained about 4 mol and F35 about 3 mol of phosphate when obtained by one-step trypsin cleavage and about 1.5 mol when obtained by two-step cleavage (Table II). The amount of 32P incorporated into F11 obtained by two-step cleavage was too small to measure and F11 obtained by direct, one-step trypsin cleavage incorporated about 3 mol of phosphate/mol (Table II). Within the limits of these assays, then, it appears that about four of the autophosphorylatable sites of native kinase reside in the COOH-terminal 54-kDa region and three in the COOH-terminal F35, with essentially all of the latter being in the COOH-terminal F11 segment and none in the adjacent F25. Its monomeric structure, its multiple phosphorylation sites, and the regulation of its activity by autophosphorylation, acidic phospholipids, and Ca2+-calmodulin make MIHC kinase an extremely interesting member of the protein kinase family. The catalytic domain, localized previously to the 54-kDa COOH terminus by alignment of chymotryptic peptides (22Brzeska H. Martin B. Kulesza-Lipka D. Baines I.C. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4949-4956Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), has now been further limited to the COOH-terminal 35-kDa region by alignment of the peptides produced by trypsin digestion (Fig. 6). The catalytic activity of F35 obtained from phosphorylated MIHC kinase is at least as high as that of the native enzyme. The mixture containing unphosphorylated F25 and small amount of F11 derived from the 35-kDa COOH terminus of unphosphorylated kinase by two step cleavage had no detectable kinase activity when assayed with synthetic peptide as substrate and did not autophosphorylate, although F11 could be phosphorylated by native kinase or large fragments that retained kinase activity. The simplest interpretation of these results is that cleavage of the 35-kDa catalytic domain at the “25/11” site disrupts the integrity of its catalytic site (Fig. 6). The MIHC kinase catalytic domain (F35) obtained from fully phosphorylated native kinase contained 2.7 mol of phosphate/mol. F11 obtained from unphosphorylated kinase incorporated 3 mol of phosphate/mol when incubated with active kinase, whereas no phosphate was incorporated into F25. Therefore, despite some experimental limitations (e.g. the calculations of stoichiometry assume 100% recovery of digestion products, 1 mol/mol could reflect partial phosphorylation of more than 1 site, and peptides might be phosphorylated differently than the parent enzyme), these data strongly indicate that the catalytic domain of MIHC kinase contains two to three phosphorylation sites, all located within the COOH-terminal 11 kDa. It is interesting that the 25/11 site is readily accessible to trypsin cleavage when MIHC kinase is unphosphorylated, but strongly protected in phosphorylated kinase. As discussed more extensively in the accompanying paper (23Brzeska H. Szczepanowska J. Hoey J. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 27056-27062Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar), the 25/11 trypsin cleavage site lies within a variable “linker” region between residues that are highly conserved in the ∼370 kinases that have been sequenced (26Hanks S.K. Quinn A.M. Hunter T. Science. 1988; 241: 42-52Crossref PubMed Scopus (3809) Google Scholar, 27Taylor S.S. Knighton D.R. Zheng J. Ten Eyck L.F. Sowadski J.M. Annu. Rev. Cell. Biol. 1992; 8: 429-462Crossref PubMed Scopus (303) Google Scholar, 28Hanks S.K. Hunter T. FASEB J. 1995; 9: 576-596Crossref PubMed Scopus (2287) Google Scholar, 29Taylor S.S. Radzio-Andzelm E. Structure. 1994; 2: 345-355Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (337) Google Scholar). Many kinases are (auto)- phosphorylated within the linker region, and this phosphorylation often affects kinase activity (for summary, see 28Hanks S.K. Hunter T. FASEB J. 1995; 9: 576-596Crossref PubMed Scopus (2287) Google Scholar, 29Taylor S.S. Radzio-Andzelm E. Structure. 1994; 2: 345-355Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (337) Google Scholar, 30Yonemoto W. Garrod S.M. Bell S.M. Taylor S.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 18626-18632Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), presumably by inducing a conformational change. For example, the crystal structure of unphosphorylated, inactive MAP kinase ERK2 shows that the linker region partially blocks the substrate-binding site (31Zhang F. Strand A. Robbins D. Cobb M.H. Goldsmith E.J. Nature. 1994; 367: 704-711Crossref PubMed Scopus (532) Google Scholar), and Cdk2 kinase (32De Bondt H.L. Rosenblatt J. Jancarik J. Jones H.D. Morgan D.O. Kim S-H. Nature. 1993; 363: 595-602Crossref PubMed Scopus (832) Google Scholar) and PKA (30Yonemoto W. Garrod S.M. Bell S.M. Taylor S.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 18626-18632Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 33Steinberg R.A. Cauthron R.D. Symcox M.M. Shuntoh H. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 2332-2341Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) must be phosphorylated within this region for maximal activity. The change in susceptibility of MIHC kinase to trypsin cleavage described in this paper provides direct evidence for a phosphorylation-dependent conformational change in this functionally important loop and a conformational change in the linker region of cyclin-dependent kinase (Cdk2) was recently demonstrated by solving the crystal structures of the inactive (32De Bondt H.L. Rosenblatt J. Jancarik J. Jones H.D. Morgan D.O. Kim S-H. Nature. 1993; 363: 595-602Crossref PubMed Scopus (832) Google Scholar) and partially activated (in complex with cyclin A (34Jeffrey P.D. Russo A.A. Polyak K. Gibbs E. Hurwitz J. Massague J. Pavletich N.P. Nature. 1995; 376: 313-320Crossref PubMed Scopus (1214) Google Scholar)) forms (for summary, see 35Pines J. Nature. 1995; 376: 294-295Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). As shown in the accompanying paper (23Brzeska H. Szczepanowska J. Hoey J. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 27056-27062Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar), MIHC kinase has a putative autophosphorylation site downstream from the 25/11 cleavage site. This is likely to be one of the sites that are phosphorylated in F11. By sequence analogy (23Brzeska H. Szczepanowska J. Hoey J. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 27056-27062Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar), the 25/11 cleavage site lies in a region that corresponds to the activation loop of PKA and the putative autophosphorylation site in the P+1 loop (29Taylor S.S. Radzio-Andzelm E. Structure. 1994; 2: 345-355Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (337) Google Scholar). Although, we were unable to determine the effect of phosphorylation on the activity of F35 (which contains F11), because we could not obtain this fragment in its unphosphorylated form, we have shown previously (22Brzeska H. Martin B. Kulesza-Lipka D. Baines I.C. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4949-4956Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) that the activity of the COOH-terminal F54 fragment (which contains F35) is enhanced by autophosphorylation. The NH2-terminal sequences of trypsin fragments F66, F60, and F35 (Table I) and chymotrypsin fragments F60 and F54 (22Brzeska H. Martin B. Kulesza-Lipka D. Baines I.C. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4949-4956Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) are all proline-rich, indicating that the middle third of MIHC kinase has a very high proline content (Fig. 6). Interestingly, proline-rich and polyacidic sequences separate the catalytic domain from the regulatory p21-binding domain of PAK (36Manser E. Chong C. Zhao Z.-S. Leung T. Michael G. Hall C. Lim L. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 25070-25078Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (206) Google Scholar), and PAK is activated by autophosphorylation within its proline-rich region as well as within the catalytic domain (37Benner G.E. Dennis P.B. Masaracchia R.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 21121-21128Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 38Martin G.A. Bollag G. McCormick F. Abo A. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 1970-1978Crossref PubMed Scopus (302) Google Scholar). Although it is not known whether this region has a similar role in all kinases, the presence of phosphorylation sites within this region of MIHC kinase (Fig. 6) raises the possibility that phosphorylation might regulate the conformation of this region as well the conformation of the linker region. This possibility is strengthened by our observation that phosphorylation of MIHC kinase increases the resistance of this region to proteolysis. The sequence similarity of MIHC kinase to the PAK family is discussed in more detail in the accompanying paper (23Brzeska H. Szczepanowska J. Hoey J. Korn E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 27056-27062Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar).

Experiments were undertaken to investigate the regulation of capacitative Ca2+ entry by phorbol ester-sensitive protein kinase C and serine/threonine protein phosphatase activity. The thapsigargin-activated Ca2+ entry pathway was probed in control cells and cells treated with phosphatase type 1/2A inhibitors, okadaic acid and calyculin A, or with the phorbol ester, phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate. The permeability state of this pathway was monitored in the presence or absence of these agents using fluorometric measurements of intracellular Ca2+ concentration, unidirectional Mn2+ entry, and membrane potential and unidirectional measurements of Ca2+ uptake using 45Ca2+. The results of these studies demonstrate that modification of the phosphorylation state of target protein(s) on serine/threonine amino acid residues by inhibition of phosphatase type 1/2A inhibits the capacitative Ca2+ entry pathway in rat thymic lymphocytes. Importantly, the capacitative Ca2+ entry pathway in rat thymic lymphocytes is not modulated by activation of phorbol ester-sensitive protein kinase C.

The correlation between the import of the Rieske iron-sulfur protein into the mitochondrial matrix and processing of the precursor protein by matrix processing peptidase was investigated using high concentrations of metal chelators and iron-sulfur protein in which the recognition site for the matrix processing peptidase was destroyed by site-directed mutagenesis. High concentrations of EDTA and o-phenanthroline inhibit import of iron-sulfur protein into the matrix. The non-chelating structural isomers m-phenanthroline and p-phenanthroline inhibit import similar to o-phenanthroline, indicating that inhibition of import is mainly independent of the metal chelating ability of the compounds.Iron-sulfur protein in which the recognition site for the matrix processing peptidase had been destroyed by a point mutation was efficiently imported into the matrix space. Import of this mutant iron-sulfur protein was inhibited by the same concentrations of EDTA and o-phenanthroline which inhibit import of the wild-type protein. These results indicate that import of the iron-sulfur protein into the mitochondrial matrix is independent of proteolytic processing of the presequence, and that o-phenanthroline together with EDTA inhibits import of iron-sulfur protein into the matrix space of mitochondria by inhibiting a step other than proteolysis of the presequence. The correlation between the import of the Rieske iron-sulfur protein into the mitochondrial matrix and processing of the precursor protein by matrix processing peptidase was investigated using high concentrations of metal chelators and iron-sulfur protein in which the recognition site for the matrix processing peptidase was destroyed by site-directed mutagenesis. High concentrations of EDTA and o-phenanthroline inhibit import of iron-sulfur protein into the matrix. The non-chelating structural isomers m-phenanthroline and p-phenanthroline inhibit import similar to o-phenanthroline, indicating that inhibition of import is mainly independent of the metal chelating ability of the compounds. Iron-sulfur protein in which the recognition site for the matrix processing peptidase had been destroyed by a point mutation was efficiently imported into the matrix space. Import of this mutant iron-sulfur protein was inhibited by the same concentrations of EDTA and o-phenanthroline which inhibit import of the wild-type protein. These results indicate that import of the iron-sulfur protein into the mitochondrial matrix is independent of proteolytic processing of the presequence, and that o-phenanthroline together with EDTA inhibits import of iron-sulfur protein into the matrix space of mitochondria by inhibiting a step other than proteolysis of the presequence.

A mutant of the plasma membrane Ca2+ pump hPMCA4b(d18-75)(ct120) containing a deletion of the N-terminal amino acid residues 18-75 and lacking the C-terminal 120 amino acid residues was expressed in COS-1 cells. The deletion in the N-terminal region did not significantly affect the level of expression of the Ca2+ pump. Tryptic digestion of the hPMCA4b(d18-75)(ct120) mutant resulted in the appearance of the same fragments obtained by proteolysis of the hPMCA4b(ct120) enzyme, suggesting that deletion of residues 18-75 neither impeded the insertion in the membrane nor extensively affected the folding of the mutant protein. The functional competence of the hPMCA4b(d18-75)(ct120) enzyme was examined by measuring the Ca2+ transport and the Ca2+ ATPase activity of COS-1 cell microsomes expressing the mutant protein. Both tests proved the mutant to be inactive. Under conditions in which hPMCA4b(ct120) becomes phosphorylated, hPMCA4b(d18-75)(ct120) was incapable of reacting with ATP and Ca2+ to form the phosphoenzyme. Taken together these results suggest that the segment of amino acids 18-75 is essential for the activity of the plasma membrane Ca2+ pump. The deletion in the N-terminal region did not significantly affect the level of expression of the Ca2+ pump.
